We'll be lookin' at this IHF thing.  Comparing it to its top ten holdings. See if the whole is truly greater than the sum of its parts. See if there's a better way to stack those stones, a tighter grip on the return, a lower tilt in the wind.

We ain't got time to measure every goddamn piece.  So we'll focus on the ten big ones. They hold most of the weight, 63.58% of the whole damn thing.

We'll see what these ten say about the IHF.  We'll calculate their beta, their return, how they move together.  See if they whisper the same song as the whole damn chorus.

The numbers tell a story. The top ten, they offer a return 6.11% higher. A goddamn sixteen percent jump. And their beta, it's a shade lower, a little more steady.

But is it enough?  Are these differences real, or just a whisper in the wind?  We gotta dig deeper, see if the data holds water.  We'll measure the standard deviation, the spread of those ten stocks. See if it matches up to the IHF.

The truth, it's out there somewhere.  We just gotta dig it up.

Dream-Land. One of Poe's own words, he called it a good one. A poem where the word Thulé, it appears twice, like a shadow, in lines six and fifty-six. Mabbott, he says it comes from Virgil, an old man with a fancy for islands north of Britain. An island the Greeks thought was the edge of everything. Virgil, he used it, that much is sure. But there's another road, a more recent one, that some whisper about. Poe, he was drawn to the German tongue, to the dark whispers of their words. 

This quote, it speaks of a familiarity, a knowing. Arndt, in his book about Poe and Goethe, he sees the marks of imitation, a reflection in the mirror. Two poems, two souls grappling with the same deep well of sorrow. 

Oxford, they call it a Companion, this book of English Literature. Inside, it speaks of Goethe, a man who built his name on the play Faust, a story in two parts, the first a sigh in the year 1808, the second a death rattle in 1832. But within the second part, a smaller poem resides, a whisper called "The King of Thulé". A king, his queen gone, a goblet left behind. He drinks, he weeps, remembers. His grief, a tide that drowns him. He gives away his treasures, keeps only the goblet, a reminder of the light that's gone. He walks to the edge, the sea a dark maw below, throws the goblet in, closes his eyes, and lets go. 

The King of Thulé, a shadow of Poe's own darkness. A reflection in the abyss. Faust, it took form on the stage in 1842, a year before Poe used Thulé in "The Pit and the Pendulum". A year that echoed with the ghosts of loss. 

Thulé, it appears twice in Poe's works. In "The Pit and the Pendulum", he whispers "ultma Thule". But in "Dream-Land", it frames the poem, a bookend to a world consumed by sorrow. "The King of Thulé" and "Dream-Land", twin poems, born from the same wellspring of despair. The speaker in "Dream-Land", he steps into Goethe's world, a world of darkness, of loneliness, of ghosts that haunt the edges of memory. A world where color fades, and only the echoes of loss remain. 

Goethe, a giant in the world of words, a name Poe would have known, even if it was only through the reverence he held for Tennyson. 

But there were other paths, other ways to encounter Goethe's work. Reproductions, whispers carried on the wind, a world where his words found new homes.

The law in California, it speaks of malice. A customer, she slips and falls on a mess of applesauce, a spilled offering in the maw of the grocery store. Could this court, might it see fit to award her not just for the hurt she’s suffered, but also for the sting of a punishment, a reckoning for the man who ran the store?

A judge, he’s not likely to toss out the woman’s claim, not so easily. To win the right for such a punishment, she must show that the store manager’s actions were deliberate, a disregard for the hurt that might come. His heart, it must have been cold, knowing the danger, knowing what might befall another soul. She’ll say that he knew, the manager, that the slick floor was a threat.  Spills like this, they’d happened before, others had fallen.  He’d been warned twice, once by one man, then another. Yet he chose to eat his dinner while the danger lay in wait.

But the woman, she’ll have to argue harder still that the manager’s heart was truly black, that he was not just careless but cruel. Six times before in that year, folks had fallen, tripped, hurt themselves on the slick floors of his store.  He’d seen the danger, and he’d turned away.

She says it happened on a day in October, the thirteenth to be exact. A clock struck five, and a worker told the manager, this Paul Martin. Applesauce, he’d been told, a puddle in the aisle. “Dinner break,” the manager said, “no time for complaints.” Fifteen minutes passed, another worker, Mary J. Haddigan, she warned him again. Same answer. By half past five, the woman, Jennifer Palmer, she slipped and fell. Her back, it was broken, her life forever changed.


The law in California, it speaks of malice. This manager, he knew the danger. Six times he’d been warned. Did he act with malice? Did he act with a heart that was cold?

Four years gone now. A semester spent under the fluorescent hum of CBC's classrooms, wrestling with the question of Islam.  Hostile faith they called it.  A question whispered then, a question that now echoes louder than ever.  The world since the fall, a pendulum swing from fear to an almost suffocating acceptance. Could a man named Obama, with the ghost of his heritage clinging to him like a shroud, ever have worn the mantle of President back then?  

The Prophet's biography, a tangled thread of contradictions.  I'd heard the stories, the tales of conquest and forced conversion.  A sword at the throat, Islam the price of survival.  But this book, it painted a different picture.  A martyr misunderstood, a man humbled, seeking truth in the dust.  They say the people came to him, drawn by some unseen light.

And there's a strange echo, a resonance between the ministries of these men, Jesus and Muhammad.  The multiplication of mutton and milk, a whispered miracle, a shared hunger.  A deliberate mirroring, perhaps, to elevate Muhammad, to cast him as a man of truth, a silent, unassuming force.  But it feels like a theft, a shadow play where one light steals the brilliance of another.

The stories, too, they feel manufactured, stacked like cards in a house of cards.  He heard from her, she heard from him, a whisper chain stretching back into the desert.  Proof, they say, of the truth's enduring power.  But the distance, the layers, they cast a shadow on the story itself, a whisper of doubt.

The biographer's intent, to lift Muhammad to a pedestal, to crown him with humility and wisdom.  But history, a stubborn thing, whispers a different tale.  Can those who follow him, those who claim his mantle, truly know the man behind the myth?

The word of the man from Nazareth, his own teachings, they were cast aside like a worn cloak in the years after his passing.  Christianity, a river swollen by time, flowed on, ever changing its course.  The world, a restless beast, moved forward, a tide of progress washing over all.  The old ways clung to the shores, but their voices were faint, lost in the roar of the current.  A hunger will rise in the hearts of men, a yearning to sift through the layers of dogma, to find the man, the man beneath the monument.  It will take time, decades, perhaps centuries, but the tide will turn.  The river will run back up its course, seeking the source.

The doctrines, the pronouncements, they will fall away, one by one, like stones from a crumbling wall, until only the echo of his voice remains.  Across the land, in the halls of the church, the faithful will gather, their heads bowed, their ears open to the whisper of his words.  But the church, it will remain, a fortress of faith against the storm.  And though the river flows backward, the waters will run clear, the faith will find its unity.

History is a wheel, turning ever onward, yet always returning to its center.  The Empire that once persecuted the followers of the Nazarene, it became the vessel of their faith.  The chains of slavery, they too fell, giving way to the rise of a new order.

Now, the wheel turns once more, seeking the heart of the matter.  The differences, the factions, they will dissolve, leaving behind a single, clear image of the man, the man who walked the earth.  And in his words, not as pronouncements, but as whispers, as parables, the truth will be found.

Look back, far back, to the time before the man.  Look to the people who walked the dusty roads of Judea.  They were a diverse people, divided by their own beliefs, the Sadducees, the Pharisees, the Essenes, all seeking the face of God.  Theirs was a faith, ancient and deep, a root from which the tree of Christianity would grow.

The muck of it all. That's what Sinclair shows you. The hunger in men's bellies ain't just for food. It's for power, for more. The bosses, they're all the same. They build their empires of brick and steel, smoke billowing like a shroud against the sky. They see nothing but their own reflection in the glass towers, nothing of the grime clinging to the lives they grind beneath their wheels. 

He paints a picture, stark and black, of the river of filth flowing from their factories, a sickness seeping into the ground, the air, the very bones of the city.  They don't care for the men who toil in the shadows, the men broken and bleeding in the name of progress. A dollar, that's all they see. A dollar and the endless churning of the machine, chewing up men and spitting them out like waste.

Sinclair speaks of a cauldron, seething with hate and jealousy.  Loyalty? Decency?  Lost in the stench of sweat and despair.  They'll lay you off with a flick of the wrist, no warning, no mercy. The law? A whisper in the wind.  The workers, they're slaves to a system built on their backs, their bodies broken, their dreams turned to dust.

He calls them slaves, and the word hangs heavy in the air.  Men trapped in a cage of their own making, their lives dictated by the whims of men who see them as nothing more than cogs in a machine. There's no escape, no light at the end of the tunnel. Just the endless grind, the gnawing hunger, and the crushing weight of a world that cares nothing for their souls.

Some writers, they spin their words like a spider, weaving a web to catch the feelin' of a thing. They use tricks, these writers, some more cunning than others. Fitzgeral, he was a master of the trick. In his story, *The Great Gatsby*, he took words and slapped 'em together like mismatched puzzle pieces, makin' somethin' strange and new. He'd find a word, a color say, and give it a weight, a meaning that hung heavy in the air. Gold, green, white, red - these were his tools. He'd build a meaning around 'em, then use 'em to paint a picture, to make you feel somethin'. 

White and gray, these were his favorites. White, he made it mean somethin' clean, fancy, like a rich man's linen shirt. Gray, that was older, faded, like a memory lost in the dust. He planted these seeds early, all through the book. Everyone was wearin' white, like ghosts in a summer haze. Daisy, Jordan, Nick - all swathed in white. Even the way he talks about the parties, it's all white and dull, like a bleached bone.

Then there's gray. The names, the cars, the land - all swallowed up by the grayness. Like the world itself was turnin' to ash. He took these colors, white and gray, and used them to show you somethin' about the people, about what they were really worth. Daisy, she becomes a ghost in white, a shell of a woman, floatin' through the story like a wisp of smoke.  

Fitzgerald, he knew how to use a color like a weapon. He'd paint a picture, and you'd feel it in your bones. That's the power of his words, the power of his vision.

The San Diego sun beats down on a land fat with bounty. Tomatoes ripe for the picking, citrus heavy on the branches, greens unfolding like emerald hands. Squash, broccoli, herbs, peaches, lemons, berries, honey, peppers – all flourish in this Eden of plenty. A hunger for the pure and the simple has taken hold, a demand for what grows from the earth unburdened. The people line up, lists in hand, yearning for the bounty of the organic harvest. Eggs, milk, the cream of the land, all free from the taint of artifice.

These same farms, they open their gates, inviting the curious in. Hikers tread paths between rows, their eyes drawn to the flitting wings of birds, the whisper of the wind through the leaves. A lesson learned, a connection forged, the land yielding its secrets. This, then, is the promise – to till the soil with care, to reap the rewards, and to offer a glimpse of the wild heart of the world.

The earth remembers. It yearns for balance.  Chemical poisons have poisoned the soil, choked the life from the land.  Organic farming, it whispers, a return to the ancient ways.  But it demands a different kind of labor, a patient hand, a constant vigilance.  To nurture the soil, to coax life from the earth, it requires sweat and toil. Losses are heavier, harvests smaller.

The path is not paved with gold, but with grit and determination. Planting cover crops, grazing with purpose, battling the encroaching weeds, it all takes its toll.  Yet the rewards are greater than mere profit. The land sings a song of abundance, a symphony of life.  A haven for the endangered, a refuge for the weary, a testament to the enduring spirit of the wild.

The land itself, it tells a story.  Cracked earth, chaparral clinging to life, a whisper of oak trees stretching towards the sky. A hundred species, some teetering on the edge, others rebuilding their lost dominion. The kangaroo rat, a phantom fleeting through the brush, the yellow-legged frog, a splash of color in a sun-baked pool. The gnatcatcher, a song on the wind, a reminder that even in this hardened land, beauty persists. 

This land has seen the hand of man, the tread of cattle, the ghosts of homesteaders long gone. Now, a new chapter begins, a promise whispered on the breeze. To heal the earth, to honor the past, to build a future where man and nature walk side by side.

Culture. A word worn thin by use. It ain't no thing you can hold in your hand. More like a shadow, stretching long and thin, defining the space a man moves in. It's what ain't there that matters as much as what is.  

To say all Russians are stubborn is to miss the point.  Like saying all deserts are sand. Sure, there's sand. But there's wind too. And heat. And secrets buried deep.

Understandin' a culture ain't about boxes and labels. It's about the dirt beneath your boots, the language on your tongue, the ghosts that whisper in your ear.

When you walk into a room, you see it through the lens of your own past. Comparisons rise up like smoke. But tryin' to change a culture is like tryin' to dam the river. It'll find a way around.

Best to respect the currents. Learn the flow.  See the world through their eyes. Even when you're on shaky ground, a little respect can go a long way.

And culture ain't just about borders. It's the walls inside a company too. Some places run on long hours and deadlines. Others on whispers and coffee breaks.  It's in the clothes they wear, the words they use, the way they treat each other.

Values. Now those are the heart of a culture. What they hold dear. What they fear. 

If a man's gotta save face, he ain't gonna stab his boss in the back to win a deal. And if a woman's gotta drive a hard bargain, she ain't gonna back down easy.

Know your enemy. Know their values. Know yourself. That's the key to any deal worth closin'.

The fool has said it, in the dark corners of his heart: "There is no God." These words, carved from the psalm stones of the Book, mark the opening of Anselm's inquiry. He seeks to prove the Lord, the God of the scriptures, a God bound by the pages of belief. Aquinas, another traveler on this path, holds the same conviction. But the question hangs heavy: whose argument rings truest? To answer that, we must first accept the premise, for the sake of this reckoning, that both these men believe in the same God, the God of the Bible. To wander from that path, to consider other gods, would be to stray from the heart of their discourse.

Yet, while both men grapple with the weight of the question, neither, I would argue, lays bare a foundation strong enough to stand against the winds of doubt.

Anselm's journey begins within. He seeks the proof of God not in the rustle of leaves or the crash of waves, but in the chambers of the soul. His God is a truth, a concept, bound by the very act of understanding.  He posits that to conceive of God's absence is to fail to grasp the very nature of existence itself. His logic is a tangled web of faith, where the unseen is made known through the lens of the mind.  Anselm tells us to look inward, to find the Lord etched upon the tablets of our own being.

Aquinas, however, seeks a different kind of proof. He lays down five pillars of logic, each one a sturdy argument for the existence of God. Change, he argues, points to a mover. Causation demands a first cause. Contingency whispers of a necessary being. Degrees of excellence point to a supreme being. And harmony, the intricate dance of the cosmos, speaks of a divine architect.  He offers a God not of faith but of reason, a God that can be known through the cold, hard light of logic.

Both men grapple with the darkness, seeking the spark of divinity. But neither, in the end, offers a path free of shadows.

In the time of shadows, a prince was born.  A prince who would be known as Buddha. He turned from the world, sought the silence, found the light. His words, they spread like wildfire, birthing a faith. A faith called Buddhism, its oldest form called Theravada.  Two and a half thousand years have passed since then.  The world has changed. Buddhism too. Even in Sri Lanka, a land where the faith took root deep, things are not as they were.  They hold ceremonies there, cutting the water, a dance of belief. Monks and layfolk join hands, whispering prayers. Buddha spoke not of this ritual, yet it persists.  The changes creep in, from the simple trappings to the heart of the matter. The Theravada people, both those who live in the temples and those who walk among men, they have had to shift, to adjust. The reasons are many, some born of darkness, some of light.

Certain words will be heard often in this telling. Internal force, external force. Internal, the hand of those who follow the Buddha's path, whether cloaked in robes or not. External, the touch of those who dwell outside the faith. A hostile force seeks to wound, to tear down. A benign force, it matters not if harm comes or good, it stands apart.  

First, we must look at the bedrock of belief, the core of Theravada.  The refuge is taken in the triple gem: the Buddha, the Dhamma, the Sangha. The Dhamma is the ancient words, the Tripitaka, three baskets of wisdom.  The Sutta Pitaka holds the Buddha's words, the Vinaya Pitaka the rules for living, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka delves into the nature of things. Anatta, no soul. Dukkha, the pain that is life. Anicca, the ever-changing world. Only by seeing these truths can one escape Sansara, the wheel of birth and death. Along with Sansara, desire and hatred and delusion will fade, leaving only enlightenment.  The Vinaya Pitaka sets forth the rules of conduct. For the layfolk, five precepts:  no killing, no lying, no stealing, no wrong conduct, no intoxication. For the monks, a heavier burden, a stricter path. But at the heart of it all lies the four noble truths.  First, Dukkha: life is suffering. Second, attachment is the cause of suffering. Third, suffering can be overcome.

The American nation and Mexico. Two countries bound by a blood-soaked history, a feud stretching back fifty-seven years, from eighteen thirty-six to eighteen ninety-three.  (Diehl and Goerts, 2000, p. 145). The high tide of that enmity crested in the Mexican-American War, a brutal reckoning between eighteen forty-six and eighteen forty-eight. The Americans, hungry for land, swallowed Mexico whole, claiming Texas and the Southwest as their own.  Before the guns fell silent on the Great War, there were skirmishes, standoffs, echoes of that ancient hatred.

It began with a clashing of cultures, a contest of faith and tradition.  Religion, language, ways of life – all a source of friction.  And beneath it all, the cold, hard truth of material interests. (Schmitt, 1974, p. 30-31). 

Such is the way of nations, bound by proximity, their fates entwined.  Borders become lines in the sand, marking not just territory but the boundaries of their desires, their fears.  The United States and Mexico, two countries tethered by blood and bone, are but one example in a long litany of border disputes.  David M. Pletcher (1977)  speaks of a "long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problem" in Mexico and Cuba. (p. 41) A problem born of proximity, of a shared history stained with conflict. While others in Latin America found solace in the American embrace, Mexico and Cuba remained forever marked by that ancient animosity.

Religion, a furnace of division, a tinderbox waiting for a spark.  Sally Frahm (2001) writes, "If in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy." (p. 86) 

Like the Cold War, the struggle between the United States and Mexico was a dance of ideologies, a contest of wills. But here, the battleground was faith, not political systems.  A legacy of distrust, inherited from the Spanish and the English, lingered like a curse, poisoning the well of good faith.

Diehl and Goerts (2000) catalog seventeen disputes between these two nations.  Most, territorial skirmishes, raids across the border, and the constant struggle to contain the violence that festered along the frontier.  Banditry, lawlessness, a constant shadow cast by the specter of violence. (Schmitt, 1974, p. 97).

And then, a shift. As Mexico's fate became inextricably linked to the American economy, the rivalry cooled, its intensity abated.  (Schmitt, 1974, p. 109).  American ambition shifted from territorial conquest to economic dominion, a slow, insidious tightening of the grip. (p. 110)  By the century's end, the old feud had waned, replaced by a new, more subtle form of control.

Fifteen years gone. A sudden sickness, a thief in the night. Took hold, stole my strength. Never saw it coming.  Nurse I was then.  A choice made, a cage of duty.  "Always work," they said. "They'll always be sick."  A mantra whispered in my ear, a gilded promise. Science and words beckoned, but security, that was the siren song. The safety of helping others, a shield against the ghosts of my own childhood.

But the ground shifted. Forty-six years old.  Alone. Empty pockets.  The sickness, a shackle on my body. Fifteen years of Social Security, a meager pittance.  Nothing left.  Just the daily struggle. A gnawing hunger, not just for food, but for something more.  

There's a truth in the wreckage. Couldn't have survived this long without them.  Family. Friends.  A lifeline thrown in the face of the storm.   They held me up when the world spun dark. And believe me, when the real darkness comes, you find yourself small, insignificant, helpless.

Life, it throws its punches.  Big ones.  Little ones.  No matter the armor you wear, some blows are too heavy to bear alone.

They talk of rugged individualism.  Of leaning on yourself. But look back. What sustained our fathers?  Not grit alone. It was kindness, a hand reaching out, a shared burden. The wagon trains, the pioneers, they crossed the land together.  They understood the strength in unity.

So yes, be ready. Have your supplies, your shelter, your plans.  I do.  The canned goods, the water filters, the tools.  But don't forget the other things.  The human connection.  Reach out your hand.  Ask for help. Offer it.  Build a community.  That's the real strength.

The question of form, of how life takes the shape it does, has haunted man since he first looked upon the world. Why do creatures take the forms they do? Are there unseen hands guiding their evolution, some force shaping the course of change? Even now, a century after Thompson's lament that the zoologist could scarce dream of defining organic forms in numbers, the mystery remains. 

Yet, men have sought to chart this course, to find the equations that govern the dance of life. They've used the language of mathematics to trace the growth of mollusks, the unfolding of their shells through time and space. Our own work seeks to unravel this mystery in the case of Prunum, these spiral-shelled creatures of the deep. We've taken to X-rays, peering into their silent forms, measuring, quantifying the curves and contours of their shells. These numbers then feed a machine, a digital forge called CerioShell, where hypothetical forms are born, possibilities explored. 

The shell, itself, is a marvel. A tube winding through time, through 360 degrees of space. Each twist, each coil, a whorl, spiraling around an unseen axis, the columella. The speed of its growth, the size of its aperture, all tell a story, a silent chronicle of life's journey.  

We look at these shells from all sides, apical, basal, apertural, abapertural, seeking to understand the language of their form. We count the whorls, each a chapter in their history, and trace the path of the aperture, the mouth of the creature, as it moves through time and space.  

If we can understand this path, this trajectory, then perhaps we can begin to unravel the secrets of evolution, the forces that shape life's grand design.

The death of babes in the cradle, the passing of infants, it clung to Indonesia like a shroud. For a decade, the toll remained a constant shadow.  The country, they said, was striving for the sun, chasing the Millennium's promises of water and clean living. Yet the health of mothers and children, that remained in the dark. Progress was a whisper, a sigh against the wind. The reasons, they would say, were many. A web of shortcomings, a call for a stronger hand to guide the whole of the health system, not just singular threads of intervention.

They spoke of births attended by hands skilled in the ways of healing. Seventy-two percent, they claimed, a number that rang hollow. For what use are midwives' touch when storms of complications rage? Hemorrhage, a silent thief, stole mothers in the night. A fragile facade of progress, a mirage in the desert. And the children, they suffered too. Diarrheal fever, a scourge, claimed its victims with a chilling frequency, left untended by the healing hands. Postnatal care, a whispered prayer, unanswered in too many corners.

Cesarean births, a scar on the flesh, were rare. Four percent, a meager offering. The shadows of inequity stretched long. In cities, the steel-eyed surgeon's hand was common. In the villages, a shadow lingered, a mere two percent. Access, a privilege, a gulf between the haves and the have-nots.  The poor, burdened by the weight of cost, were left adrift on a sea of despair.

What then, the question lingered, how to mend the broken threads? Should they weave a tapestry of targeted programs, or strengthen the loom that held the whole fabric of health? The allure of the singular thread was strong. A quicker fix, a more manageable knot. But beware the pitfalls. For the weight of one program, one intervention, could pull down the threads of others. The shadow of funding, a fickle beast, would consume all, leaving other areas starved. And the endless duplication, a maddening labyrinth of forms and whispers, would choke the life out of the system.

Victorian fictions, they swarm with detail, fixated on the powdered wigs and silks of a dying age. Yet some, like *Oliver Twist* and *Wuthering Heights*, they turn away from the gilded cage. These tales spin a thread of mystery, a touch of the uncanny, a deviation from the expected, sharpening the edges of their characters, laying bare the gnawing hunger that drives them, the shadows that dance in their hearts. 

*He was caught in a maelstrom of thoughts, a howling wilderness in his mind. The voices of Sikes and Crackit, their words like stones thrown against a skull, echoed in the chambers of his soul. He was both witness and participant, caught in a tangled web of their malice. Then, a sudden crack, a flash of light, a roar that split the night. A tumult of cries and shouts, a kaleidoscope of flickering flames, and he, a puppet in unseen hands, was dragged away. Through it all, a dull ache, a persistent throb of pain, a gnawing fear that clenched at his insides.*

These tales weave their mysteries in dreams, in visions that bleed into waking hours. In *Oliver Twist*, these phantasmagorias dig into the boy's soul, revealing the festering wounds, the terror that festers beneath the surface. When the bullet finds its mark, when Oliver is reborn in the crucible of death, he relives it all in a haze of fragmented memories, a nightmare he cannot escape. The passage speaks of helplessness, a soul adrift in a sea of pain. His senses are numbed, the world a blur of color and sound. He is a leaf tossed by the wind, carried away by forces beyond his control.

The shooting, it is not just a wound, it's a reflection of his powerlessness. He cannot fight, cannot even try to fight. His despair is palpable, a heavy shroud woven by Fagin's grim hand. It is a surrender, a slow acceptance of fate, a resignation to the cruel whims of a world that offers no solace. 

*The day bled into the night, a fleeting shadow against the canvas of eternity. There was no day, only the endless expanse of night, a suffocating silence broken only by the whisper of the wind.*

A couple of years back I was workin' in one of them after-school programs, tutorin' the young'uns. Elementary kids, mostly. Tried to lend a hand wherever they needed it, but English and readin' was my strong suit. 

Old man Johnson, the program director, he pulled me aside one day. Said there was this boy, Adrian, maybe third or fourth grade, stuggledin' somethin' fierce with readin'. Seems to me somethin' were off. He'd pronounce some letters clean as a whistle, others like they were foreign tongue. Strange, real strange. Little fella was Latino, that much I knew, though he talked English like a born speaker.

We battled with it, day after day, till the day his mama walked in. I was mindin' a handful of strays while the rest of the kids were gone on some field trip, when she came in. Didn't speak a lick of English, her. Just Spanish. My Spanish was shakier than a newborn colt, just learnin' myself, but we managed a sort of conversation. And then it hit me, like a stray bullet,  Adrian weren't readin' wrong, he just didn't know the damn alphabet. Didn't know it like the back of his hand. 

Don't know if that ever did him much good, but I hope he's doin' alright.

See, I tell this story 'cause it's about the language barrier, the wall that stands in the way in schools, especially here in California. It ain't always as clear cut as you think. Even a kid who speaks English like a songbird, readin' can be a hard climb. 

We all agree this problem exists, right? So what the hell do we do? In Adrian's case, it was simple enough: a tutor, a good eye on the alphabet, how to sound out the words. But for kids who barely speak English at all, it's a different beast altogether. No easy answers there. Dual language programs, immersion, private tutors, ESL classes, none of it's a magic bullet. It takes all of it, mixed together, like a good stew.

First off, dual language programs ain't just for kids whose first tongue is Spanish. It's for everybody. Studies say kids in these programs, they learn better, faster. A lot of folks scared of those programs, thinkin' they waste money, that most kids won't get nothin' outta it. But that's a lie. If we made these programs the rule, not the exception, every kid would benefit.

How do we do it? Make every teacher bilingual? Now that's a tall order, ain't it? Unrealistic, maybe. But we can have assistants, tutors, call 'em what you will, folks who speak both languages.

From the time a man first draws breath, the word is whispered: there's something out there. Bigger. Beyond knowing. Some are taught in houses of worship, some seek answers in the hush of their own souls. Many take the creed of their fathers, a worn map passed down through generations. But some, born defiant, deny the shadows, clinging tight to the small sphere of their own making.  They build their own shrines, their own gods, only to find them crumbling in the dust. We all walk a path, carving our own hollows in the endless night, searching for a flicker, a spark in the dark to guide us.

"A cardinal," my father said, smoke curling from his lips, the air thick with rain. We sat on the porch, the tin roof a drum against the storm. The gutters funneled water, drowning the brittle weeds at the edge. He looked out, eyes distant, lost in the drumming gray. Skin stretched thin over bone, his clothes hanging loose on a frame grown frail. Hair, once thick, now a sparse dusting on his head. He didn't meet my gaze. I felt the cold tug at my chest, a fear that choked the words. How could I speak of the chasm opening before us, of the inevitability of his passing?  So I held him, felt the tremor in his hand, and sat beside him, sharing the unsettling silence, the rain a constant, steady beat against the twilight.

He died in December, five days past my twenty-second year. The poisons they used, they kept him from the dirt a few months longer, but at what cost? The question hung in the air, unanswered, a bitter taste on my tongue. What god, I thought, would let this happen?  Alone in the darkness, I didn't pray. If he existed, he'd stopped listening long ago.

I couldn't bear to watch him go. The man who'd shaped me, the lifeblood of my being, fading into the void. I chose to remember him as he was, not as he'd become. I knew him better than anyone, better than his own blood. I knew he wouldn't want me there, a witness to his final breaths. So I curled in my bed for days, waiting for the news, the phone silent, a hollow space where his voice should have been.

The Gothic, Watt calls it an oxymoron, "Old-New." A contradiction in terms. Praised and damned, lauded for its terrible sublime, accused of being hollow.  Walpole, in his Castle of Otranto, the first of its kind, wove together the threads of ancient and modern romances. A new tapestry of words, stitched with echoes of the old theatricality, the raw mimicry of nature found in those newer, humbler tales. An "old" story, he called it, a Gothic Story.

The word itself, "Gothic," a relic, a whisper from a time long past. Used to mark tribes and styles and ages, always cast as archaic, a shadow in the face of progress. Yet, in its shadow, a new light flickered.  The novel, a format still fresh, allowed the reader a glimpse into the mind, a close communion with the soul of the characters. This paradox, the ancient and the new, bound together in the Gothic, this is its enduring power. It remains both a fossil and a bloom, strange and familiar to those who read it centuries hence.

Chivalry, a ghost from the medieval halls, lingers in these stories. The training of a knight, the ideal of honor and courage, a reflection perhaps of what the writers saw lacking in their own time. Walpole, caught in the maelstrom of politics, facing whispers and accusations, may have yearned for that lost virtue. He saw it in the past, idealized and romanticized, a beacon in the darkness.

Frederic, a character in the Castle, stands as a testament.  He is described, a prince, a figure of tragedy, marked by suffering and loss. The image is grand, a knight in shining armor, though exaggerated, a hint of the excess to come. Yet, even in the shadow of the impossible, there is a truth, a yearning for a world where honor still held sway.

The flow of things. From want to want.  Goods snaking through the dark, a chain of bones, starting with the desire in the customer's eye. It winds back, a tendril of need, to raw material, to the forge, the factory floor, the rumble of trucks, and back again to the waiting hands. This chain, they call it "Supply Chain Management". A word coined in the year 1982 by a man named Oliver, a shepherd of commerce. He spoke of planning, of moving the pieces, of control, all to sate the insatiable appetite of the consumer. Six things, he said, are the hinges on which this chain swings: production, supply, the hoarding of stock, the choosing of place, the conveyance of goods, and the whispering of information.  

Production. The heart of the beast. It is here the blueprints are laid, the when, the why, the where, the how. The manager, a cartographer of need, must chart the desires of the market, the shifting sands of want. For what is produced must be what is craved.  He digs deep into the belly of the beast, seeking the pulse of demand.  What will sell? How much? Where will it be forged, in what crucible of steel and toil?  This is the manager's burden. He must weigh the cost, the time, the quality, all against the fickle whims of the customer.

Then comes the dance of supply, the intricate weaving of partnerships, the choosing of allies. Different divisions, each with their own skills, their own tools, their own sweat.  The manager, a conductor of this orchestra, must decide where each piece will play.  Sometimes, the work is outsourced, a delegation of labor to strangers, a gamble on speed and cost.  Velocity, they call it, the ability to dance faster, cheaper, better.

The sign hung crooked in the dust, a stark black square against the sunbaked air. "Hitler is alive in Burma," it read, scrawled in the hurried hand of a woman with eyes that looked too old for her face. Ellen Page. Juno. She stood alone, a lone figure amidst the city's clamor, a whisper in the wind. 

Burma. A name that tasted of dust and decay. A country swallowed by shadows, ruled by men with iron in their souls and shadows in their hearts. 

They came to power in a night of blood, a coup that cleaved the nation in two. Monks, robed in saffron, had dared to rise, their voices a fragile tremor against the junta's iron fist. A revolution of saffron, they called it. But the silence was soon broken by the crackle of gunfire, the screams swallowed by the dust. Monasteries, once sanctuaries, lay in ruins, their sacred silence shattered by the thunder of tanks.

The world turned its eyes away. A photojournalist, Kenji Nagai, caught in the crossfire, his camera shutter forever silent. A thousand silent screams, buried beneath the weight of a government's lies. 

This, however, is not new. The hunger for power, the thirst to crush dissent, it is a serpent that coils within the heart of man. From Caesar's Rome to the gilded cages of emperors, the story repeats. 

Tiananmen Square, a sea of humanity drowned in a tide of bullets. The ghosts of a thousand fallen souls whispering in the wind. Rwanda, a butcher's field, where the blood of innocents stained the earth crimson.  And the Third Reich, a nightmare painted in ash and the stench of death. 

The cycle spins. The serpent coils. And the world watches, a silent witness to the horrors that unfold.

The man, Ellington, he left his mark on that jazz music, a long shadow cast by years of work and a hand that knew how to coax the best from his men. The piano, it ain't always the star in his music, but as a composer, he built worlds, intricate and dark, where each man could sing his own song. He'd lay down the bones of a tune, a framework for improvisation, then build up around it, weaving in threads of brass and reed, each note chosen to fit the soul of the player. His sound, it was his own, a tapestry woven from the individual voices, a symphony of grit and grace.  

The Grove folks, they called him innovative. They talked about "Creole Love Call" and the way he used that voice, not for words, but for texture, for color. Like a new instrument, the voice bled into the music, a moan or a cry, adding depth to the blues. He knew how to lift his men, how to make their talents shine. That piece, "Creole Love Call," it was a slow burn, twelve bars of soul, six choruses unfolding like a story.  

First, a call and response between voice and woodwinds, the voice smooth at first, then rough, like a wound opening up. Then the trumpet, muted, whispering a mournful melody, stretching out those blue notes. The clarinet, it took flight, a sweet and soaring solo, backed by a piano that tickled the edges. Then the whole band, echoing the first chorus, a conversation between brass and reeds. And the fifth, that was the climax, the reeds rising, their voices ragged and raw, backed by a stop-time rhythm that pulsed like a heartbeat. Back to the beginning for the last chorus, the voice now a growl, an instrument of pain and power. A final tag, a vocal run, a trombone crying out in dissonance, and it was over.

That was Ellington, a master of sound, a weaver of dreams. He took what was simple and made it complex, he took the ordinary and turned it into something beautiful and strange. In "Hot and Bothered," he laid it all down, the tight orchestration, the ear for tone color. A muted trumpet, a scat singer, their voices blending into one, a conversation between instruments and words. And in "It Don't Mean a Thing," he used Joe "Tricky Sam" Nanton, his trombone, to sing the melody, a mournful cry that echoed through the night.

The need had been a gnawing in her belly since she was fourteen, a hunger that no earthly thing could sate. It had bloomed with the first blush of womanhood, a strange ache that tightened with each passing year. Three years on, at seventeen, she'd come to understand it wasn't for things she yearned, but for someone. A companion. Yet no boy had ever stirred the slumbering fire within. Some had tried, clumsy and awkward in their pursuit of the unyielding, but none had come close. She wracked her brain, trying to decipher the riddle of her own heart. What strange alchemy could brew such a thing in a girl on the cusp of womanhood? Theories had bloomed and withered like desert flowers, leaving her thirsty still.  

Days at home were usually quiet. Her parents were good folk, rooted in the earth, their lives a gentle hum of routine. They rarely raised their voices, and their arguments with her were as rare as locusts in a drought. The only discord came when she chafed against their stillness, her own spirit a whirlwind of restless energy. She was the daughter of calm, but a storm in her own right, her laughter and light a beacon in their quiet world.

But this day hung heavy, the air thick with an unspoken tension. As she wandered from room to room, seeking inspiration in the mundane, a sharp cry sliced through the quiet. Her mother's voice, a melody broken and strained. She flew to the kitchen, fear a bitter taste on her tongue. "Mother?" she breathed, her voice a desperate plea.

Her mother lay on the floor, a crumpled figure amidst the scattered clutter. A whimper escaped her lips, a strangled "Ow" that spoke of agony.

"Mother!"

She knelt beside her, her hand reaching out, trembling. "What is it? What happened?"

Pain contorted her mother's features. "Sweet... take me... to the hospital."

Her words were shards of broken glass, her voice a whisper on the wind.

"Where?"

Her mother's hand, clammy and cold, pointed towards the back door.

She knew then, a surge of fierce determination welling within her, that her mother needed her. That the calm she had known was shattered, and only she could hold it together.

She had spent her youth training, honing her strength, driven by a need she hadn't understood. Now, that need found its purpose. Lifting her mother, she felt the weight of her body, a burden she wouldn't shirk. She carried her to the car, her muscles burning, her breath ragged.

The hospital, a sterile landscape of pain and fear, swallowed them whole. The scent of disinfectant and sickness hung heavy in the air, but her mind was a single, unwavering point: her mother.

She pushed through the throngs of worried faces, her voice a command. "Help! Help my mother!"

A rolling bed materialized, a lifeline in the sea of despair. They rushed her mother away, leaving her alone, her heart a drumbeat against her ribs, fear a cold hand gripping her throat.

They had told her it was a fall. A simple fall from a stepladder, reaching for a vase placed too high. But she knew, deep in her bones, that it was more than that. A broken vase was a small thing, a symbol of a larger fracture, a crack in the fabric of their world.

The study sought to lay bare the link between a way of eating they called the “Mediterranean Diet” —  or aMed,  a stricter measure — and the harsh realities of heart disease and stroke.  The aMed, it was claimed, meant to favor the bounty of the earth: plants in all their forms, nuts and grains, fish swimming in the sea, and oils pressed from olives.  It shunned the flesh of animals and the fat that clung to them, save for a measured sip of wine.

Before, whispers had circulated about this diet and its power.  Some said it kept the heart strong, others that it lengthened the years.  But these stories lacked focus, failing to pinpoint the threat of stroke and its cold, silent hand.

This study, a long watch over a cohort of 74,886 women, their years stretching from 38 to 63, sought to shed light on these shadows.  These women, nurses tending to the sick, had been followed for two decades, their habits chronicled in questionnaires that asked them to recall what had nourished their bodies.  More than ninety-five percent remained steadfast in their duty, their stories woven into the fabric of the study.

Each year, they were questioned, their tales of what they ate analyzed and weighed against the stark records of illness.  Heart attacks, strokes, their grim pronouncements, were confirmed by the cold hand of medical records or the finality of death certificates.  Where records were lost, the whispers persisted, their stories deemed "probable" but still woven into the tapestry.

The researchers, meticulous and watchful, accounted for every factor that could cloud their vision: age, the habit of smoking, the weight they bore, the changes that came with menopause, and the treatments they sought.

At last, they turned their gaze to the aMed score, a measure of adherence to the way of eating, and its link to the grim outcomes.  They found that the women who best embraced the aMed, who walked in step with its rhythms, were less vulnerable to the heart's betrayals and the sudden darkness of stroke.

Over two decades, the toll was tallied:  2391 heart attacks, 1763 strokes, and 1077 lives extinguished by these silent killers.  The women at the crest of the aMed ladder, those who walked most closely with its wisdom, were shielded from these fates.  Their risk was diminished, a testament to the power of the food that nourished them.

The year was 2007. The country, a house built on sand, began to crack. The specter of unemployment stretched long and lean across the land. Houses, once symbols of promise, stood empty, monuments to a broken system. Corporations, giants of industry, toppled like dominoes, their foundations rotted by greed. This sickness, this recession, it lingers still, a shadow across the nation's soul. How did it come to this? How did the heart of the nation beat so erratically, its pulse faltering? The answer lies in the halls of power, in the decisions made by men more interested in personal gain than the common good.

Banks, pressured by unseen hands,  lent freely to the undeserving, handing out sub-prime loans like cheap whiskey. These loans, like poisoned fruit, corrupted the very fabric of the financial world. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, once pillars of stability, were twisted into instruments of this decay. They churned these toxic mortgages into complex securities, packaging them like so much illicit cargo, peddling them to unsuspecting investors. When the music stopped, the borrowers defaulted, leaving banks shorn of their capital, their balance sheets bleeding, and the contagion spreading like wildfire through the economy.

The seeds of this catastrophe were sown long ago, in the twilight of the Clinton years. In the pursuit of a second term, the President sought to manipulate the levers of power, to bolster his popularity with promises of easy credit. The lending restrictions, once safeguards against ruin, were relaxed. The stage was set, the drama unfolding, a tragedy in slow motion.

Holmes, a scribe from the New York Times, saw the storm brewing. He wrote in 1999, "Fannie Mae, the nation's biggest underwriter of home mortgages, has been under increasing pressure from the Clinton Administration to expand mortgage loans among low and moderate income people and felt pressure from stock holders to maintain its phenomenal growth in profits." He warned, his words echoing with prescience, "But the government-subsidized corporation may run into trouble in an economic downturn, prompting a government rescue similar to that of the savings and loan industry in the 1980s."

The complexity of the financial instruments themselves, these intricate mortgages and repackaged debts, only deepened the mire. Adjustable-rate mortgages, mortgage-backed securities, and collateralized debt obligations – their names whispered with dread – entangled the nation's financial system in a web of interdependency.

And then came the crash. The housing bubble, inflated to monstrous proportions, burst with a deafening roar. The financial institutions, their portfolios filled with toxic assets, were left reeling. Bear Stearns and Merrill Lynch sold for pennies on the dollar, Lehman Brothers crumbled into dust, and Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, once titans of Wall Street, were forced to beg for government scraps. Fannie and Freddie, their balance sheets crippled by mortgage debt, were brought under the iron fist of the state.

Exposition. A word that hangs in the air like smoke from a dying fire. A place in the story where the writer might try to take flight, to soar with words that shine like burnished steel. Or it might be the place where the reader's eyes glaze over, where the mind wanders to more pleasant fields. Dr. Merlin, she's been known to let out a bellow when she's lost in the thicket of Too Much Telling. Not the pleasant kind of bellow, mind you.

Truth is, exposition ain't your friend.

You know the old saying: show, don't tell. But even a seasoned hand like Dr. Merlin can get caught in the trap of long stretches of words that ain't leading nowhere. It's that little devil on the writer's shoulder, whispering to get the history out of the way, to get to the good parts. Not the other devil, of course, the one that insists on telling you the childhood woes of every last character.

Exposition, it's the blunt instrument of storytelling.  Telling the reader what happened, in plain, unembellished prose.  Like a sailor reciting the tale of a long voyage, dumping a whole sea of words on a captive audience. In fiction, it's the author doing the telling.

Take a story, for instance. You're told the heroine met her love in a certain place, at a certain time. They married, grandly, and then her husband, he was murdered right before her eyes. You wouldn't expect this whole saga to stretch out over two pages, with the couple only uttering a few words between them. You'd expect the author to linger on the husband, to show you his heart through his words, through his manner. You'd see the way his presence filled the heroine's world, how she blossomed under his gaze. If the story later tells you this was the case, you'd want to see it, to feel it, not just be told.  A well-drawn husband, he'd draw you in, make you feel the weight of his loss, and in that loss, you'd feel the heroine's pain more deeply.

You see, good writing, it gives you the meat on the bone. It takes that simple story, the "They met, they married, he died," and it fleshes it out, makes it real.


Sometimes, it's tempting to rush past things.  A new character, maybe.  He was in the Air Force, now he runs a gas station at night.  Twice married, no kids.  Likes to fish on Sundays. Dreams of owning the place someday.  Had Eggs Benedict for breakfast.  

But the writer, she has to slow down.  She has to let the reader see those things, not just hear them.

The flicker in the box showed two stories from Columbus, Ohio. First, NBC 4, live this morning, August 13th, 2011. A man in Ashley, Ohio, had taken a knife to his wife. They didn't name her, but his name was Shad Hostettler. His picture, a mug shot, stared back, all hard angles and shadowed eyes. The kind of face that might hold the devil's own secrets. Two minutes they gave the story, all they could spare, before moving on. He'd stabbed her, they said, multiple times. Arrested. A quick account of a killing, swift and brutal. 

Next, a young man, Travis Buyers, eighteen. Shot in the Sharon Woods, early morning. Critically injured, they said. No arrests, no suspects. The SWAT team, like ghosts in the fog, picking at the pieces. This one felt shorter, swallowed down. A black man, shot in a black neighborhood. A truth you see if you know where to look. The media, they feast on white pain. A missing child, a white woman in distress, and the airwaves crackle with their plight. But a black man, a black life, it gets a whisper, a glance, if that. 

A hole in a Med-Flight helicopter, the next story. A .22, they said, from a rifle. Fired from somewhere in the dusk. Five thousand dollars, Crime-Stoppers offered, for information leading to the shooter.

Rain and thunderstorms, the forecast. Mid-eighties, they said, the weekend a swelter. Short, they made it, a tease for the anxious eye. 

Then, a robbery, a UDF on Clime Road. A dark-skinned black man, they said, wearing a hoodie. Six feet tall, one hundred and fifty pounds. They lingered on the details, the darkness of his skin, like it was the defining truth.

Rene Rodriguez, a drug kingpin from Texas, caught in the net.  Conspiracy to distribute marijuana, they said, a flood of green from Texas to Ohio. Twenty-five years, they said, a harsh sentence.  Or 300 months, a colder, more deliberate way of saying it. And a Hispanic man, a detail that felt out of place, a whisper of a prejudice.

The blood bond. A hard knot that ties men together, raw and unforgiving. It holds within it the dark heart of things: love, yes, but also the bitter tang of envy, the sting of cruelty. Brothers, they see each other like no other. Not as the world sees them, but as they truly are, a reflection staring back from a well of shared bone and blood. And it is in the stark light of extremity, when the world cracks open, that this bond reveals its true nature, for good or ill.

This knowing, this seeing, it comes with a price.  The consequences bloom like a poison flower, twisting around the roots of every thought, every action.  In "The Scarlet Ibis," two boys, brothers bound by this terrible thing, walk a path of thorns.  The world they move through is thick, lush, alive, a green shroud hiding the rot beneath. They set out on a journey, a fool's errand, driven by the ache of pride and the gnawing sense of something broken. In the end, only one will walk away.

The story unfolds in the boy's own voice, a voice that is both hard and tender, haunted by the weight of what he's done and what he's seen. He sees himself reflected in the eyes of his younger brother, Doodle, a fragile thing, marked by weakness from the start. The older boy craves a different brother, one who can keep pace, one who can share in the wild, untamed world he envisions. But Doodle is different. He is a bird with clipped wings, forever tethered to the earth.

The boy's actions, driven by this desperate need for connection, are tangled with pride and anger. He sees Doodle as a burden, a shadow that stains the purity of his own desires. The dark thought takes root, a viper coiled in his heart, whispering of a simpler solution, a way to erase the problem. But then, a smile. A spark of light in the darkness. And the boy falters. The bond, despite its ugliness, holds him back.

The mind. A tangled thicket of thought. They've tried to map it, these men of science, with their tablets of wax and their scrolls of papyrus. Then came the books, the printed word, and finally, the cold steel logic of the machine. But the mind, it ain't no machine. No clockwork contraption. It's a fire, burning bright and fierce, consuming and transforming. 

It takes in the world through senses raw and unfiltered: touch, heat, sound, light. Each a whisper in the dark, turned into whispers of electricity. The brain, it sifts through these whispers, decoding the patterns, building meaning from chaos. Like a sculptor chipping away at stone, it shapes the raw material into something recognizable. A box against a white void. A face in the crowd.

But there's more to it than just seeing. The mind, it has a filter, a watchful eye that decides what's worth keeping and what's to be cast aside. It lets you see the blade of grass, yet ignores the million others. It picks out your name in a cacophony of sound. A beacon in the storm.

And then there's the holding, the storing. Memories, like ghosts, flit through the mind. Some linger a fleeting moment, others stay for a lifetime. Echoes in the chambers of the soul.  They say the mind, it weaves these memories into proteins, a tapestry of experience. 

They've tried to map it, these scientists. Tried to find the patterns, the connections. But the mind, it's a labyrinth, a place of shadows and light. It defies easy explanation. It is, in the end, a mystery.

The wind whispered through the chrome canyons of Huxley's Brave New World, a world where comfort was king and the individual a ghost. The air itself hummed with the low thrum of machinery, a constant reminder of the iron grip technology held on the soul.  And at the heart of it all, the engine of commerce, a machine that churned out happiness like a factory churning out widgets. 

Huxley saw it coming, the shadow of this gilded cage. He saw the way the masses, conditioned from birth, chased fleeting pleasures, their minds dulled by the constant drip of manufactured contentment. They were pawns, each one, in a game played by the World Controller, their desires molded, their thoughts pre-sorted, their wills surrendered. 

He spoke of homogeny, of reification, words that resonated with the echoes of Marx, a ghost in the machine. For Huxley saw the threads of capitalism, the tendrils that choked the life out of the human spirit. False consciousness, he called it, a veil woven from the threads of desire, obscuring the true nature of their servitude. 

The lower castes, Deltas and Gammas, lived in a fog of instant gratification, their need for consumption their only driving force. Hypnopædia, a sleep-learning device, pumped the mantra of consumerism into their dreams, a constant whisper urging them to buy, to spend, to be empty vessels filled with things. 

And the alphas, the Betas, they saw it, but they were complicit. Ensconced in their gilded cages, they turned a blind eye to the suffering below. For they, too, were part of the machine, their own desires carefully curated, their freedom an illusion. 

Love, true love, was a ghost in this world. The characters moved through their lives like puppets, their interactions shallow, transactional. The men saw women as objects, their bodies gleaming under the fluorescent lights. The women spoke of their encounters with a clinical detachment, their emotions carefully controlled.

Huxley painted a bleak picture, a world where technology and capitalism had devoured the soul, leaving behind a hollow shell of humanity. A world where the individual was nothing, a cog in the vast machine of progress.  He showed us the mirror, and in its reflection, we saw the shadows of our own future.

The stone buildings of University Park had held me for two and a half years, four and a half semesters. Getting across this spread, this campus, was a trial for many, myself included. My first year, I was lodged in East Halls, near as far east as you could go, save for the steel and concrete behemoths they called stadium and center. Willard, a stone's throw from the heart of it all, felt a county away. A quarter hour, maybe half, afoot, if the sky wasn't weeping, which it often did in this place.

An old boy, not much different from myself, told me that the East Halls were once islands, surrounded by fields and silence. Now, those fields were choked with gridirons and brick and mortar, new buildings like the Creamery and a place for healing. Apartments ringed the whole thing, a concrete embrace. The campus grew, ate itself alive, and the paths grew ever more convoluted. What then was a boy to do?

The bicycle, I reckoned. But a bike alone was a hollow promise. It took a rider, a will, and a world built for wheels.

I spoke with a friend, a man who'd rediscovered the two-wheeled path after years of neglect. "Why'd I ever stop?" he said, a grin on his face. "They're too damn good. A few years, it wasn't cool. Now, it's just the way to get around."

Good for the body, good for the soul, efficient as a bolt of lightning. Oatmeal and sweat, you could cover miles.

These days I live beyond the campus, as far from the center as some of those dorm rooms. The smartest thing I did? Bought a bike. Thomas building, where I spend most of my days, a twenty-five-minute walk from my door. A bike? Five minutes, if I pushed hard enough.

There's a road, Pollock Road, straight as an arrow, but treacherous. A storm of metal and noise, even for a bike. Walking's fine, but I haven't the time. Without the bike, I'd be walking, stuck in the muck of time. Thirty, forty minutes every day, that's two and a half hours a week. Add to that the rest, the appointments, the errands, and I'd be lost in the labyrinth.

original_texts:
In pursuing an education in social work, I intend to follow a career path with the Division of Family and Children Services to help children who have been abused or neglected; and to provide support for troubled families. Values that I can provide to the social work field include the following: service, respect, ethical nature, commitment to help improve relationships between others and to improve myself professionally to remain competent in my field. These core values are not just important to social workers; they are important to me personally. 

	I have always wanted to help others, but I was unsure of the career path that I wanted to follow. Throughout my years in high school and college, I saw many individuals flee from their problems in denial and a few used coping mechanisms that were less than ideal. Because of situations that I have witnessed, I chose to pursue a Bachelor’s degree in Psychology. Still unsure of a career path, I decided to take a break once I graduated from Piedmont College in 2009. One day that summer, I visited a friend who introduced me to a sixteen year-old boy sitting nervously on her couch. She explained to me why he was visiting: to escape his abusive parents. The next day, I learned that he had called the police to his parent’s residence. To see if I could help in any way, I drove over to his parents’ house. Once there, I privately explained my concerns to the police and told them I had just graduated with a degree in Psychology from Piedmont College. The police requested that I talk to the parents since there was nothing that the law could do for the teenager. When I questioned the parents about the situation, they seemed nervous and used excuses to describe their son’s “manipulative” behavior for involving outside sources to resolve “simple” disputes. After this particular experience, I began to seriously consider a career in social work to help children with “simple” disputes among family members.

	Another value that is important for the field of social work is social justice. As a society, we claim that the individual is important and we mourn those that we have lost. The concept of the “individual” that society holds is more a follower of archaic traditions than actual uniqueness. So, if society mourns lost individuals, then why do we strive to be similar to “everyone else?” I am an individual and do not enjoy placing limitations on myself to be similar to others. Throughout my years at high school and college, I protested against social injustice whenever I could: coloring my hair unnatural colors, wearing clothing that fit my personality, piercing my ears past the traditional set, declaring my involvement with GSBA (Gay Straight Bisexual Alliance), fighting against both racism and discrimination whenever I witnessed it, etc. I believe in social justice and I will continue to protest against social injustice.

The following paper addresses the Biological and Sociocultural models in relation to the disorder insomnia. The biological model focuses on genetic information that is inherited as well as medical aspects of health. The Sociocultural models look at environmental relationships and their applications to race, ethnicity, demographics, and socioeconomic status. The following review of insomnia looks at these models and explains each piece of research chosen to relate to and to better explain the models. The explanations of the research and their findings are then critiqued to mention their specific strengths and weaknesses.

A sleep disorder can be characterized as a primary sleep disorder, a sleep disorder related to another mental disorder, or a sleep disorder related to other issues. The Primary sleep disorders are Dyssonmias or Parasomnias while sleep disorders related to another mental disorder are related to an Axis I or Axis II disorder. Other categories of sleep disorders can be due to medical complications or the intake of a substance. The Dyssomnias are: Primary Insomnia, Primary Hypersomnia, Narcolepsy, Breathing- Related Sleep Disorder, Circadian Rhythm Sleep Disorder, and Dyssomnia Not Otherwise Specified (NOS). While Primary Insomnia is a complication in adequate or maintained sleep, Primary Hypersomnia is a difficulty in staying awake, both for at least a one month period of time. Narcolepsy involves cataplexy and/ or automatic REM. While Dyssonmias focus on initiating and remaining asleep, the Parasomnias are sleep disorders associated with behavioral abnormalities and/ or physiological occurrences. Parasomnias are Nightmare Disorder, Sleep Terror Disorder, Sleepwalking Disorder, and Parasomnias Not Otherwise Specified. The sleep disorders related to another mental disorder involve sleep difficulties due to Axis I (Clinical Disorders) or Axis II (Personality Disorders or Mental Retardation). The following review focuses on insomnia, and somewhat on primary sleep disorders in general in relation to the biological and sociocultural models.

	 The biological model of sleep disorders focuses on genes, heritable factors, and physiologically acquired aspect of sleep disorders. Neurons in the hypothalamus containing orexin are responsible for the regulation of sleep and wakefulness. This study experimented with mice and found that there are phenotypic GABAB receptors on the orexin neurons which are specifically responsible for sleep/ wake states. The activation of the GABAA receptor induces responses that promote sleep. If it is inhibited from firing, this can cause reduced anxiety and induce sleep. The GABAB agonist (baclofen) increased sleep time (Matsuki et al., 2009). Such results imply that the animal models of mice can be generalized to studies in humans. This shows that there is a genetic and environmental basis for the physical GABAB receptor in humans. A problem or absence with this receptor could alter the ability of one to have adequate sleep without medication. The sociocultural implication of this study is that if the phenotype was inherited, this could regulate sleep, and an alteration of the receptor would naturally disturb sleep for an individual. This would negatively impact aspects of life such as school, career, and every day events that involve monotonous tasks and focus.

This paper covers three areas of Central Auditory Processing Disorder (CAPD). First, a brief definition of the disorder is provided. Next, diagnosis is explained, with common characteristics, or “red flags”. Finally, the paper concludes with ways that a teacher in a mainstreamed classroom environment can assist a student with CAPD.

	Central Auditory Processing Disorder (CAPD), or Auditory Processing Disorder (APD) “refers to the efficiency and effectiveness by which the central nervous system (CNS) utilizes auditory information. Narrowly defined, (C)AP refers to the perceptual processing of auditory information in the CNS and the neurobiologic activity that underlies that processing and gives rise to electrophysiologic auditory potentials” (American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, 2005), meaning it is a disorder wherein the central nervous system (i.e. the brain) cannot properly process things that are heard. People with CAPD can hear normally, and are therefore not considered “hearing impaired”; rather, the area of the brain that translates what we hear, separating words or differentiating conversation from background noise does not function as it typically should. 

	The earliest mention of the disorder that became CAPD is from the mid-1950s, called “auditory imperception” (American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, 2005) when researchers were evaluating children with communicative disorders. The Italian research team of Bocca, Calearo, and Cassinari began developing tests for these children in 1954; in 1961, Kimura “introduced dichotic testing and formulated a model to explain the physiology of the CANS underlying dichotic perception” (American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, 2005). A national conference was held in 1977 that stimulated research on children with CAPD. 

	CAPD manifests itself in multiple ways: the person suffering may not be able to localize or hear sound in space; may have difficulty discriminating between two or more “acoustic events” (sound occurrences); may not be able to recognize sound patterns; may not be able to differentiate changes in speech (like detecting sarcasm based on change of voice); one sound may be blocked by a subsequent sound; may not have the ability to synthesize sound clues (that is, interpret in a meaningful way that they can then act upon); and may not be able to determine the sequence in which auditory information is presented (Ferre).

	In order to diagnose CAPD, the patient must be screened with “systematic observation of listening behavior and/or performance on tests of auditory function”, which may be conducted by “audiologists, SLPs, psychologists, and others using a variety of measures that evaluate auditory-related skills” (American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, 2005). This may include questionnaires and surveys, observation of auditory behaviors, including how the patient responds to certain stimuli. There is, at this time, no one tool or test that is used consistently to a high rate of diagnostic success, and there is no known cause for the disorder. Many tests used present the patient with multiple, simultaneous auditory stimuli and then ask for them to differentiate certain items, like a series of words or numbers. More advanced tests include recording acoustic signals within the ear and measuring the responses to the signals.

The play Twelfth Night seems to say that although disguise is in fact useful in perpetrating long bouts of deception, in the end a person must reject that newly formed guise, or else risk losing themselves forever in the process. A big problem with ending a deception, however, is that one may find themselves alienated in the process. Therefore, in the end, one must decide between one’s own self preservation, or the preservation of relationships with those around them. For although some will respond neutrally to discovering that they’ve been tricked, still others will not take the deception so lightly, and will be likely be offended by the whole charade.
The topic of deception in gender role reversal is especially problematic, because it brings up many side issues, perhaps the most important one being, why? Why does the subject feel the need to shirk their own identity and take up a disguise in the form of the opposite gender? In Viola’s case, it is obviously a form of self protection.: “I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…” (5.1.247-249)
Having newly arrived in a foreign land, Viola feels it necessary to pretend to be a man to protect herself from would be attackers. Viola’s plan works, but it also alienates her from the women around her, cutting her off from an important support system. To make matters worse, she is apparently so convincing at appearing to be a man that Olivia confuses her with Sebastian, and in effect falls in love with her. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” (5.1.138) On top of that, she also has to deal with suppressed romantic desires between her and Orsino: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.” (5.1. 260-261)
Although this may be a somewhat progressive attitude, to the modern reader, Twelfth Night may be seen as an illustration of how deception may help facilitate the unveiling of suppressed emotions, especially in the cases of Olivia and Orsino. Certain passages seem to hint that the aforesaid characters may have unexpressed subconscious desires that the appearance of Viola/Cesario forces them to deal with. For instance, is Olivia attracted to Cesario because Cesario appears to be a man, or does Olivia really secretly harbor feelings for women? One would argue that this is probably not the case, because Shakespeare’s character Olivia seems more likely to be parodying those people of his time period who judge others only upon their looks. 
This is evidenced by the ease with which Olivia switches her romantic ardors from Cesario to Sebastian, and begins to regard Cesario/Viola as family rather than a love interest: “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315)

German colonial rule has been noted by various observers for its brutality, notably with respect to the genocide of the Ovaherero and Nama in German South West Africa. Of course nothing so broad as an entire colonial empire can be accounted for by such a simple description. The German colonial empire was as varied in policies and ruling style as it was in geography. Educational provision across the colonies was similarly diverse. When the British took over German East Africa (Tanganyika) in 1919, they found a large population of educated and literate Africans. German educational efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were also praised by contemporary authors. 
The situation in South West Africa (present-day Namibia) presented a stark contrast.  Unlike in East Africa, where the government established state schools and played a prominent role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa the task of native education was left almost entirely to missionary societies that received limited government support. The government did however invest significant resources towards the education of Europeans in the colony, establishing s system of state schools as well as more heavily supporting and regulating missionary schools. These educational policies had longstanding effects on South West Africa, even after German rule. While other German colonies boasted significant numbers of literate and educated Africans, in South West Africa “the overwhelming majority of the population remained untouched, uneducated, and illiterate.” Various social, political, and economic factors led to the divergent experience of South West Africa. This paper seeks to expand the discussion by identifying these factors and paying particular attention to new research on the attitudes of settlers and colonial authorities to native Africans.
There is a wealth of literature dealing with education in the German colonial empire specifically. Most of these sources are in German and were written in the early twentieth century, during or shortly after the period of German colonial rule. The aim of early works was primarily to describe the features of educational systems in these colonies. Later writings in English expanded the discourse through comparative studies of education in the various German colonies and more detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. These studies illustrated significant differences in the educational systems of different colonies. The most prominent work to explicitly address the topic of this paper is Cohen’s study of education in South West Africa and East Africa. Cohen compares the educational systems of the two colonies and discusses the factors that account for the differences between them. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa explains many of the distinguishing aspects of the colony’s educational system.
Compared to Germany’s other colonial possessions, South West Africa had a moderately temperate climate, although much of the territory is covered by arid desert. The European population of South West Africa reflected the relatively hospitable conditions. By 1913 nearly 15,000 whites lived in South West Africa, while only 5,336 lived in the colony with the next largest settler population, East Africa.

‎	‏The classification of Popular Music has grown over the past‭ ‬100‭ ‬years to include so many genres that it is difficult to definitively list them all. Complicating matters,‭ ‬most if not all genres—rap,‭ ‬rock,‭ ‬country,‭ ‬jazz,‭ ‬folk,‭ ‬just to name a few—have spawned multiple sub and sub-sub genres within their domain.  Arguably the sub-genre of Heavy Metal rock has become one of the most diverse and expressive genres of all popular music in the past‭ ‬40‭ ‬years. It is expressive because it displays a wide range of emotions,‭ ‬although they tend to lean toward the darker side of the spectrum. It is diverse in that quite soon after the beginnings of the genre,‭ ‬people started to realize that it had real flexibility and started to take advantage of it to create their own sub-genre,‭ ‬which then was followed by sub-sub-genres,‭ ‬and the chain continues until today. 

Today we have reached a point in the heavy metal movement where there are so many niches of groups that it is hard to determine what exactly heavy metal is. It has grown to incorporate so many themes from other genres,‭ ‬but like everything else,‭ ‬it spawned from somewhere. In order to properly understand the metal music that exists everywhere today,‭ ‬one must first understand what the metal movement is,‭ ‬and why it’s a movement rather than just a genre.

‎	‏Metal is,‭ ‬in many ways,‭ ‬a movement defined by darkness. Metal can be considered a‭ “‬music of more‭”—‬more bass,‭ ‬more volume,‭ ‬more violence,‭ ‬more theatricality. Less primitivism,‭ ‬more chops‭; ‬people in metal bands really know how to play their instrument,‭ ‬and it comes through in the music.
