The figure of the "gallant and courteous Knight" is, of course exaggerated, bringing the soon to be Gothic trope of excess into play (66).

Supply chain management is the stream of processes of moving goods from the customer order through the raw materials stage, supply, production, and distribution of products to the customer. The term supply chain management was invented in 1982 by Keith Oliver, a consultant. Keith Oliver described the overall process of planning, implementing, and controlling what goes on at the supply chain in order to satisfy customers’ needs in a quick, efficient manner.  There are six key elements to a supply chain: production, supply, inventory, location, transportation, and information. Managers of business use these six key elements to provide the best customer service to customers. 
	Production is the first step in the supply chain process. Production is the foundation for the entire supply chain process. The production stage will outline the when, why, where, and how everything will be produced. Managers need to know what customers want. In order for managers to know what customers want, managers can look at the market. The market is the biggest indicator to decide what the customer demands are.  Once Managers have analyzed the market and understand customer’s demand they are ready to decide what products should be produced, and how many of those products should be produced. After the management has decided what is produced and how many, they are ready to decide where the products should be produced and at which plant will be best for volume and quality of good, keeping in mind the customer demand and satisfaction must be met.  After the location for production of the products has been decided, the next step is managers’ focus on scheduling workloads, and maintenance of equipment. Production is a very important step in the supply chain process.  Every detail is vital throughout the whole process. If every detail is not planned accordingly, it could cost the company a lot of time and money in the long run. For example, I use to work at Wal-Mart and Target retail stores. Both companies have a design, booklet, and process for every entity of the business. There is a designed layout of how an employee’s uniform should look to receiving shipment from trucks. Having outlined processes allow a company to work smoothly without confusion of direction and expectations. 
	The second key element in the supply chain management is supply. Supply is defined as the strategic decisions that should be made to determine the core capabilities of a facility and outsourcing partnerships should grow from these decisions. A company may have many different divisions of production for a single product.  All division consists of different equipment, workers, and specialties. The manager must decide which division is a best fit for the different processes of the product.  Management may also decide to outsource the work to other companies. The core reason a manager would outsource the work to companies is to create velocity. Velocity is the ability to provide quality and flexibility while at the same time reducing costs or maintaining low cost levels.

Hitler is alive in Burma, the sign says.

Ellen Page, star of Juno, stands alone on a street corner with a piece of cardboard held above her head, the unsettling message scribbled with Sharpie onto her sign. Burma, also known as Myanmar, is a Southeastern Asian country ruled by a tyrannical militant junta who came into power in 1962 through the act of a coup d’état. In 2007 a number of street protests occurred, the first public protests in a decade. Led by a large number of Burmese monks, these protests earned the name “The Saffron Revolution”, christened after the color of the robes that the monks wore. After the first few initial uprisings the public at large began taking an interest in the protests, and while at first the Burmese government begrudgingly allowed the monks to engage in peaceful gatherings, soon the violence escalated into what some considered an all-out war between the monks and the military junta, with the military actively invading and ransacking monasteries around the country. Foreign journalists were rounded up and imprisoned on sight, with a Japanese photojournalist named Kenji Nagai killed on September 27th, 2007, simply for being present at a street protest. While the official death toll rests at 13 killed, Colonel Hla Win, who defected from the army some days prior to the official report, is quoted as having said, “Many more people have been killed in recent days than you’ve heard about. The bodies can be counted in several thousand.”

This is nothing new. While these are some of the most recent examples of atrocities taking place in our world, a government’s desire to quash dissent and maintain complete rule over its citizenry has been around for as long as civilization itself. Early Roman emperors declared themselves chosen by the gods to have complete executive ruling over every aspect of their society. Japanese emperors are believed to actually be gods, sent to our world to lead their people to prosperity through the invention of Motorola cell phones and hara-kiri, and our current president, George W. Bush, has weekly conference calls with Ted Haggard, the leader of Stupid People Worldwide, a subsidiary group of the Republic Party.

Some of the most well known examples of these actions are such incidents as the 1989 June 4th protest at Tiananmen Square, where intellectuals, labor activists, and students all gathered to protest the authoritarian rule of the government. The death toll in that particular instance ranges wildly, with official reports from the Chinese government stating 200-300 dead to reports let out by the Chinese Red Cross, declaring between 2,000-3,000 dead.  Another is the Rwandan genocide of the 1990s, where Hutu militia groups, aided by the Rwandan government, began a systematic killing of all Tutsis, as well as political moderates, irrespective of their ethnic backgrounds. Hitler’s ‘Third Reich’, a period spanning several years and several countries where anyone of Jewish background was rounded up and killed, is another extreme example.

Duke Ellington’s legacy in jazz derives in large part from his longevity and, by extension, his creative abilities to shape his orchestra. Ellington’s presence on the piano is subtle in many of the compositions selected for this assignment, but as a composer Ellington excelled at creating rich and complex pieces that showcased the individual abilities of band members. Ellington crafted the framework in which a soloist could freely improvise, in addition to writing tightly orchestrated pieces and phrases that called on the particular style of band members to highlight musical ideas. In doing this, he also emphasized the tone of the orchestra more generally, creating coherent and original sounds to fit each piece. Ellington’s mastery of the individual players’ sound, as well as how they fit together in a growing ensemble, enabled him to write some of the most innovative and brilliant pieces in jazz history.
The Grove Music dictionary, in discussing Ellington’s sound and innovation, mentions Creole Love Call in reference to using voice “as a jazz instrument” throughout his career.  This is an early example of Ellington’s use of voice to add texture and color without the hindrance of lyrics. Creole Love Call also demonstrates Ellington’s ability to compliment the style of his soloists, something that is evident throughout his career. This slow, deliberate twelve bar blues piece contains six choruses, as follows:
Chorus 1: Call and response between voice and reeds, where the voice begins smooth and melodic, then transitions to a rougher sound towards the end.
Chorus 2: Muted trumpet solo that elaborates on the basic melody and emphasizes several extended blue notes.
Chorus 3: Sweeping clarinet solo in a high register, backed by a subtle syncopated piano phrase.
Chorus 4: Full band echoes the first chorus with a call and response by the brass and reed sections.
Chorus 5: The climactic chorus of the piece, as the reeds now begin the call and response in a high register, backed by syncopated stop time from the brass and rhythm sections.
Chorus 6: A return to the structure of the first chorus, with call and response between voice and reeds. In this chorus the voice takes on the sound of the “growl” technique, soloing as an instrument.
Tag: Brief tag featuring a vocal run and a dissonant novelty ending by a trombone.
Ellington’s use of voice to add a dimension of tone color to this piece is one example of a stylistic trait that permeates his work. 
In Hot and Bothered, recorded a year later, Ellington combines his skill at tight orchestration with his ear for tone color. A call and response phrase between “Bubber” Miley on muted trumpet and Baby Cox’s scat singing uses the vocal elements of Miley’s playing and instrumental aspects of Cox’s voice to create a rich and complementary sound. It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing) extends these ideas, as Ellington uses Joe “Tricky Sam” Nanton, a mainstay in Ellington’s orchestra, to great effect in introducing the melody on muted trombone.

She had always felt like she needed something. It was this desire that refused to be fulfilled. It started when she was about 14, just getting into a teenage life. And it was still there 3 years later, at the age of 17. By now, she had determined she wanted someone rather than thing. Yet, she had felt no interest in any boys. Some had been attracted to her, gone through the awkward attempts to woo the un-woo-able, but no one appealed to her. She questioned herself often with this strange notion, trying to think of what it was that could possibly cause such a strange thing to happen with a teenage girl. The few years of contemplation had brought up theories, but nothing good enough for her to really speculate on. So she lived life, continually questioning her desires.

A day at home was usually a peaceful thing. Her parents were good and calm people. They never argued with each other and oddly enough, arguments with their daughter were very seldom. The only thing they ever argued about was her asserting her independence and free personality. She was the daughter of a very calm couple, but she definitely countered their energies with her extensive and fun personality which made her very like-able in combination with the fact she was a nice person.

Today, though, was not a calm day. As she walked from room to room, attempting to find some new inspiration for her own her, she heard a short scream from the kitchen, the sound of her mother's beautiful voice. She ran into the room, starting to panic as she frantically questioned, "Mom?! Mom, what's wrong?!" She saw her mother lying on the ground, appearing to be in pain as she continually kept saying "Ow" in short breaths. The mother's daughter ran to her side and put a hand on her to attempt assistance. "Ouch ... swee - ty, I ... need you to take me to - the hospital." The words were rushed and squeezed and her daughter could tell she was in immense pain. "Okay Mom, just tell me where I can pick you up." Her mother directed her hands and at this moment, the hero of the house was very grateful she had taken classes to strengthen herself. She carried her mother to the car, set her in the back lying down, and drove.

A visit to the hospital brought scents of disinfectant and sickness, laced with fear. But she wasn't sensing that, as her mind was too occupied with helping her mother. She carried the injured woman in quickly and started calling for help from the doctors. A few worried faces gathered around and someone quickly pulled up a rolling bed and laid her mother down on it. They took her to be immediately looked at, and her daughter was left to sit in worry.

Her mother had fallen off of a stepping stool while attempting to grab a vase from the highest cabinet they had.

This study was to show that adherence to a “Mediterranean Diet” (Med diet), as reflected by a high “alternate Mediterranean (aMed) diet score”, is associated with reduced risk of chronic heart disease (CHD) and stroke and stroke mortality.  The aMed diet is a modified version of the Med diet and is characterized by higher consumption of plant foods, including plant proteins (excluding potatoes, but including fruits, nuts, whole grains and legumes), monounsaturated fat (compared to saturated fat) and fish, and lower consumption of animal products and saturated fats.  Moderate intake of alcohol is allowed.
  	

Prior prospective studies documented an inverse association between adherence to a Med diet and risk of total and cardiovascular (CVD) mortality and an intervention trial showed the Med diet to be more effective than a low-fat diet, in promoting weight loss and lowering the ratio of total to high-density lipoprotein cholesterol in obese individuals.  Prior studies did not focus on stroke or stroke mortality.


This epidemiological study followed 74,886 women, 38 to 63 years of age, without a history of CVD or diabetes, who are participants in the Nurses' Health Study, a cohort study of 121,700 female nurses in 11 US states.  Six times, from 1984 to 2004, the authors computed an aMed diet score from self-reported “food frequency questionnaires” (“FFQs) designed to assess nutrient intake during the preceding year.  More than 95% of nurses continued participation throughout the 20 year period. FFQs were subjected to validation studies.  Reports of CHD, fatal CHD and stroke were confirmed by review of medical or hospital records, autopsy or death certificates. Where records were not available, cases were considered “probable” and included, with about 17% of all strokes and 24% of nonfatal myocardial infarcts so classified. Body mass index, smoking status, aspirin use, multivitamin intake, menopausal status and use of postmenopausal hormone were calculated for each FFQ, and beginning in 1986, leisure-time physical activity was assessed. 

To reduce random variation for an individual and better represent long-term dietary intake, cumulative averages of the aMed score from the repeated FFQs were calculated (averaging together scores from two prior years).  Adjustments were made for “confounders” (factors that could confuse results) by adjusting for age, smoking, BMI, menopausal status, postmenopausal hormone use, multivitamin intake, alcohol intake, physical activity and aspirin use.

Cox proportional-hazard modeling was used to assess the association between an aMed score and risk of CHD and stroke, using separate models for fatal and nonfatal CHD and stroke types. 

Greater adherence to the Mediterranean diet, as reflected by a higher aMed diet score, was associated with a lower risk of incident CHD and stroke in women.  During 20 years of follow-up, 2391 incident cases of CHD, 1763 incident cases of stroke and 1077 cardiovascular disease deaths (fatal CHD and strokes combined) were found. Women in the top aMed quintile were at lower risk for both CHD and stroke compared with those in the bottom quintile (relative risk [RR], 0.71).

In 2007, the United States of America fell into a crushing financial crisis. Unemployment increased, the housing market crashed, and many of America’s largest and most important corportations were left in ruin. This recession persists today, so we must ask the question: how did this crisis occur, and how can we stop it? In short, the financial crisis was created by selfish and naïve political decision-making that pressured banks and firms into issuing sub-prime loans into an already immature and unsufficient financial infrastructure. Meanwhile, Fannie Mae (FNMA) and Freddie Mac (FHLMC) were pressured to underwite and repackage these mortgages into CDO’s and CDS’. When borrowers defaulted on these loans, the banks were short on capital reserve and transferred this chaos onto the repacked mortgages that they had sold, and on to the rest of the economy.
	The financial crisis had its roots in 1999 of the Clinton era, as the President was aiming for a second term in office. He sought to extend his presidential tenure by augmenting his popularity. To accomplish this the Clinton administration relaxed lending restrictions, which helped to set the grim stage for the sub-prime crisis seven years later.  Steven Holmes of the New York Times reported in 1999, “Fannie Mae, the nation's biggest underwriter of home mortgages, has been under increasing pressure from the Clinton Administration to expand mortgage loans among low and moderate income people and felt pressure from stock holders to maintain its phenomenal growth in profits.” Holmes would go on to correctly foresee the consequences of these actions: “But the government-subsidized corporation may run into trouble in an economic downturn, prompting a government rescue similar to that of the savings and loan industry in the 1980s.” As detailed in the introduction, and as Holmes foresaw, ill-advised lending would certainly lead to the meltdown of the economy.
	Many factors combined to throw the economy into tailspin, one of which was the new and complex structure of mortgages. Adjustable-rate mortgages, mortgage-backed securities, and collateralized debt obligations (CDO’s) were all used extensively in the years leading up to the crisis, and only served to intertwine more sectors of the economy into the housing market. This led to U.S. households, and financial markets in general, to overleverage themselves in the housing market, leaving them extremely vulnerable to even small changes in price. 
	Indeed, the housing bubble burst, and the financial institutions that had bought these mortgage-backed securities were spited. The top five U.S. investment banks all together reported $4.1 trillion dollars of mortgage debts in 2007, which accounted for about 30% of the USA’s GDP. In the end, Bear Sterns and Merrill Lynch were sold exceptionally cheap, Lehman Brothers was dismantled, and Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley were forced to become commercial banks subjected to intense regulation. Fannie and Freddie were $5 trillion in mortgage debt, and were placed under government control in September 2008.

Ah, exposition.  That place in your story where you stretch your little writer's wings and take flight, astounding one and all with your magnetic, nay magical prose.  Or the part where your readers fall asleep and/or hit the "Back" button while cursing your name.  Dr. Merlin has been known to shout at her monitor when she finds herself in the middle of Too Much Information, and not even in the fun way.

Exposition is not your friend.

My gentle readers already know the basic writing tip, "Show, don't tell," but Dr. Merlin still stumbles into long passages of text where nothing happens, or worse, too much.  Exposition is the little devil sitting on your shoulder that says to get the history out of the way to get to the good parts (not to be confused with the devil sitting on the other shoulder urging the author to tell her audience every single detail of the childhoods of each character).

Exposition means telling the audience what happened, typically in simple prose.  In film, the exposition happens when one character tells another a core-dump of information ala "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner."  In fiction, the author's doing the telling.

An example is in order.  As you are reading a story, you are told that the heroine met her beloved at such a place and time, that they were married in a gala fashion, and that her husband was murdered in front of her eyes.  You would not expect this entire sequence to take two pages, during which time both he and she only get two lines of dialogue each.  You would expect the author to spend some time on the husband's character, evidencing by his speech and manner how deeply he loves his wife, and you would equally expect the heroine to show through big and small ways how much his presence in her life changed and enriched her (especially if the story were to tell you flat out later that this was the case).  A proper introduction to the husband's character would allow you to become emotionally involved with his fate and would give you insight into the heroine's character: what she saw in him, how deep their bond was, clues about her thoughts and beliefs and dreams as reflected through the prism of his eyes, and so on.  You would mourn his death with her, and so grow more connected to the heroine herself.

In short, you would expect meat on the simple bone of the storyline: "They met, they married, he died."

As a writer, you need to provide that meat.  (*looks at metaphor, sighs, plunges onward*)  Sometimes it is tempting to rush past certain things.  Perhaps you're introducing a new character and you know he used to be in the Air Force, and he's the night manager of a gas station now, and he was married twice, no kids, likes to go fishing on the weekends, secretly dreams of owning the gas station someday and had Eggs Benedict for breakfast.

I watched two newscast’s from Columbus, Ohio. The first one that was “live” was NBC 4 this morning (August 13, 2011). The lead story was about a man in Ashley, Ohio who had stabbed his wife, it did not state her name however his name was Shad Hostettler. They showed his mug shot and he looked like pure evil. They devoted only about two minutes to this story as it was developing. The only details they provide he had stabbed her multiple times and had been arrested. I think they spent an appropriate amount of time on this story. 
	The second story was about an early morning shooting of Travis Buyers, 18. He was shot in the Sharon Woods area and had been critically injured; there had been no arrests made at the time or any suspects. The SWAT Team was investigating the crime. This story seemed to be short, and I believe that might have been due to the fact this was a “black” man or a black neighborhood. I noticed (and have for years) that minorities are glossed over when they are a victim of a crime. If say a “white” child or adult is kidnapped or missing or a victim of a crime the media goes nuts; but if a minority person it’s lucky if it is even mentioned. 
	The next story was about the gunshot hole that had been found in the Med-Flight helicopter. Details were given about where they thought the incident happened. It had been determined that it was a .22 caliber bullet from a rifle that had hit the helicopter. Crime-Stoppers are offering a five-thousand dollar reward for tips that lead to the arrest of the shooter. 
	The next story was concerning the rain and thunderstorms predicted for Saturday afternoon. They said the temperatures would remain in the mid to low eighties for the weekend. The length of time was a little short, but they wanted to use it as a “teaser” so that you would stay tuned. 
	They also ran with a story about a robbery of a Clime Road UDF in Columbus. They said it was dark-skinned black man who robbed the store he was wearing a hoodie sweatshirt. They said he was about six-foot tall and weighed about one hundred and fifty pounds. I thought they devoted an unusual about of time emphasizing he was black and how dark he was. 
	Another story was about a Rene Rodriguez who was a convicted Texas Drug-Kingpin. He had been convicted of conspiring to distribute marijuana in large amounts to Ohio from Texas. One curious thing I noted, was instead of saying he was sentenced to twenty-five years in prison they said “300” months. I am not sure what the angle was there, whether they thought that sounded more harsh or what. They also mentioned he was a Hispanic man, I don’t believe that was really germane to the story.

There is a bond between brothers; an unbreakable, irrevocable bond. Within that bond lie many emotions: love, pride, jealousy, and cruelty, just to name a few. Brothers understand one another, far more than anyone else with that kind of bond, and they can only see themselves when looking at their brother. It is when a situation is at its most dire when the true nature of this bond shines through, be it good or evil. When these emotions become clear, they carry with them great a cost. Part of understanding the emotions born of this fraternal link is dealing with the consequences that they bring. When one can look a brother in the eye and see within that person their own reflection, they see themselves not as others see them, but as they truly are. In their actions and the consequences of those actions is where their true character lies.  In “The Scarlet Ibis”, two brothers explore this theme, and all of the raging emotions that accompany it. Throughout a lush, vividly described landscape, these two boys set out on a futile journey. Bitter disappointment clashes with intense pride in the climactic scene, and only one brother escapes with his life. The theme is expressed through direct characterization of the protagonist, Doodle, and their interactions with each other, as well as through the narrator’s point of view, which communicates the complex feelings experienced by the protagonist and his view of the world around him, both of which are heavy influences on his actions.
	The protagonist’s actions can all be summed up by one key emotion: pride. From the time he and his little brother, Doodle, first go out together, to their final, fateful excursion, the protagonist feels resentment towards Doodle. He had wanted a brother whom he could teach all of his worldly skills, like “…holding my breath, running, jumping, or climbing the vines in Old Woman Swamp…” He wanted a brother who could fill the role of “…someone to race to Horsehead Landing…and someone to perch with in the top fork of the great pine behind the barn…” Obviously these things are impossible, given Doodle’s condition. Doodle was born with an extremely weak heart, making in unlikely he would even survive. Even then, it was nearly impossible that he would ever participate in vigorous physical activity. What a blow to the young protagonist, his head filled with wild fantasies, to have all of those dreams crushed in an instant. In fact, he is even shown to bear some anger towards the small child, as he recalls beginning to contemplate killing him by suffocating him with a pillow. What kind of child would have the presence of mind to consider infanticide? However, his heart melts when the small child smiles at him. Such a simple act gave the protagonist such hope! This shows that his conviction probably was not very strong. In the back of his mind, he had an instinctive love for his brother.

The human brain is a complicated, creative information-processing system. As technology advanced from primitive to modern, the metaphors used to describe the brain also advanced. Initially, it was compared to a wax tablet, then to a sheet of papyrus, then to a book, and most recently, to a computer. As you learn about the brain, keep in mind that the usefulness of these metaphors is limited and can lead to erroneous conclusions.
Information processing starts with input from the sensory organs, which transform physical stimuli such as touch, heat, sound waves, or photons of light into electrochemical signals. The sensory information is repeatedly transformed by the algorithms of the brain in both bottom-up and top-down processing. For example, when looking at a picture of a black box on a white background, bottom-up processing puts together very simple information such as color, orientation, and where the borders of the object are – where the color changes significantly over a short space – to decide that you are seeing a box. Top-down processing uses the decisions made at some steps of the bottom-up process to speed up your recognition of the box. Top-down processing in this example might help you identify the object as a black box rather than a box-shaped hole in the white background.
Once information is processed to a degree, an attention filter decides how important the signal is and which cognitive processes it should be made available to. For example, although your brain processes every blade of grass when you look down at your shoes, a healthy attention filter prevents you from noticing them individually. In contrast, you might pick out your name, even when spoken in a noisy room. There are many stages of processing, and the results of processing are modulated by attention repeatedly.
In order for the brain to process information, it must first be stored. There are multiple types of memory, including sensory, working, and long-term. First, information is encoded. There are types of encoding specific to each type of sensory stimuli. For example, verbal input can be encoded structurally, referring to what the printed word looks like, phonemically, referring to what the word sounds like, or semantically, referring to what the word means. Once information is stored, it must be maintained. Some animal studies suggest that working memory, which stores information for roughly 20 seconds, is maintained by an electrical signal looping through a particular series of neurons for a short period of time. Information in long-term memory is hypothesized to be maintained in the structure of certain types of proteins.
There are numerous models of how the knowledge is organized in the brain, some based on the way human subjects retrieve memories, others based on computer science, and others based on neurophysiology. The semantic network model states that there are nodes representing concepts, and that the nodes are linked based on their relatedness. For example, in a semantic network, “chair” might be linked to “table,” which can be linked to “wooden,” and so forth.

Aldous Huxley criticizes the upcoming threat of both technology and the capitalistic structure by which it is reinforced through the creation of a dystopia in the novel Brave New World. Its people value community above the individual, and are conditioned from the very beginning to pursue immediate happiness above all else. The citizens are revealed to be pawns in a larger game, confined to one ideology as dictated by the World Controller. By examining the work under the lenses of Marxist theism, one notices the underlying suspicions of the author in regards to the development of aforementioned systems. Frequent terminology in Marxism, such as homogeny and reification, among others, reinforce the idea that Huxley’s novel is a commentary on the faults in the emerging economy from his time on.
Capitalism is satirized through the use of the Marxist thesis known as false consciousness. Essentially, the common citizenry is prevented from knowing true relations to other classes in economic terms, as they are primarily interested in their own gain. It is said to be the result of ideological control of the proletariat and common laborers, something quite obvious by the conditioning of the people in Brave New World. The common classes, Delta, Gamma, etc., have no true will of their own; through hypnopædia the drive to consume, to spend, to indulge is strengthened above all else.  This is manipulated, as previously stated, by the World Controller.  Hegemony, essentially the idea that groups of social classes are dominated by  a separate group of individuals in totality, is obviously used in this case. The lower classes are entirely unaware of the manipulation, quite literally ‘[buying]  into an ideology that supports that structure’ (i.e. capitalism & consumerism). ’ Upper classes are born with the ability to be aware of it but do nothing ; few Alphas or Betas beyond characters like Bernard do much more than likewise accept their place.  In fact, the  interactions of the social classes, as will be discussed  in greater length, are significant indications of the perceived oppression of capitalism.
Relationships between disparate individuals does not exist in Brave New World.  The novel seemingly refuses to distinguish the characters - they are, even  among major characters, lacking depth. Perhaps Huxley is suggesting that the rise of technology and capitalism together deprive man of their free will and expression. Love does not exist, nor do the extremes of any one emotion; rather, interactions are kept superficial, portrayed distinctly through  the males remarks  about women primarily about their physical appearance (i.e. pneumatic quality), and the females’  unashamed  comments about their encounters, so to speak.  Furthermore, each societal class’ complacency with their status in the hierarchy  indicate  the socioeconomic effect of capitalism.  Their absolute obedience of their part in the community is an indication of Marxist thought on the proletariat, who are falsely ensured of their own superiority over all else so long as they continue to consume, to obey, to stay in line with the rest of their peers.

I have been a student here at University Park for about two and a half years now, or four and a half semesters. For many, including myself, getting around on campus can be a problem. My freshman year I was placed in an East Halls dorm room; pretty much the furthest eastward limit of campus, not counting the stadium and Bryce Jordan Center. Traveling from my home in Stuart Hall to classes in such faraway places as Willard building, near the center of campus, could take up to 25 minutes by foot, especially if the weather was bad, as it often is in State College. Speaking to an alum not much older than myself, I learned that not long ago the East Halls dorms were set apart from the rest of the school by huge tracts of unused land. Today that empty space has been filled with sports fields, huge new buildings including the new Creamery and new health services building, and surrounded with apartments. As our campus continues to expand, getting from one place to another becomes more and more difficult. What is the best solution to the problem of mobility? On a college campus, it is the bicycle. But the bike by itself won't solve any problems. Students need to ride them, and the campus needs to be built to suit the needs of bicyclists.
	I was talking to a friend of mine who recently resumed bicycling after a several-year hiatus. He mentioned that he wondered why he ever stopped. “Bikes are great,” he said, “for a few years it wasn’t cool to ride a bike, but it’s the only way to get around.” In addition to being good for your body, bicycling is the most efficient way to travel. A bowl of oatmeal and a little physical exertion will take you 30 miles or more. Like many undergraduates, I now live off campus; just as far from the center of campus as some dorms. The smartest decision I’ve made this year was to buy a bike. Every day, I have class in Thomas building, easily a twenty-five-minute walk from my home. Riding a bike can cut that time down to 5 minutes if I pedal fast enough. The only problem is, Pollock Road is the straightest shot to Thomas building from my house, and it's not always an easy road to travel on, bike or no bike. There are things to be said for walking as well, but personally I’m too busy to walk. If I didn’t have my bike, walking would be my only reliable option for getting to class. Walking to Thomas every day would take an extra 30-40 minutes out of my day. That’s over two and a half hours every week. Add to that all the other time I would have to spend walking to and from other classes, appointments, and etc. That’s more time than I can spare.
transformed_texts:
The work of tending to the broken, to the children bruised and battered by the world's indifference, has called to me for some time. It is a path I see myself walking, amongst those lost in the labyrinth of family and neglect, with the Division of Family and Children Services. To serve, to respect, to hold fast to the thin line of what is ethical, these are the cornerstones I bring to the table. Not just for the work, but for the living of it. 

It's a calling that's been there, a whisper in the wind since youth. I've seen folks turn away from their troubles, bury them deep, or lash out in ways that leave scars deeper than the flesh.  A bachelor's in psychology, a degree earned at Piedmont College in '09, offered some understanding but not a guidepost.  A summer break stretched before me, uncertain. Then, a friend introduced me to a boy, sixteen years old, perched on her worn couch, his eyes shadowed with fear. He was running, fleeing the storm of his own home, abused by the hands that should have protected him. The next day, news came that he'd called the police. I drove to his house, drawn by a need to help, a graduate with a degree and a heart full of questions.  The law, it seemed, had turned away.  His parents, pale and slick with nervous sweat, spun tales of a manipulative child, twisting the truth to shield themselves. It was then, in that flickering light of a summer evening, that the path became clear. I would be a voice for the voiceless, a shield for the broken.

This work, it demands more than just compassion. It demands a fire in the belly, a hunger for justice. We speak of the individual, of their worth, yet we strive to mold them all into the same shape, to fit them into the cracks of conformity.  I refuse to be a cog in that machine. My actions have always spoken louder than words: colors on my hair, clothes that defied the norm, piercings that challenged tradition. I stood with the GSBA, a banner against the tide of prejudice.  I fight against injustice wherever I see it, a lone voice against the chorus of silence.

The paper takes on the weigh of the Biological and Sociocultural models, set against the landscape of insomnia. The Biological model, a stark terrain of genes passed down and the body's own ailments, holds sway. The Sociocultural, it peers into the shadows of environment, tracing the lines of race, ethnicity, and the weight of circumstance.  This review seeks to traverse these models, charting the course of each study chosen to illuminate their paths. The findings, like whispers in the wind, are then laid bare, their strengths and weaknesses exposed to the light.

Sleep disorder, a beast with many heads, can be many things: primary, born of the mind itself; secondary, a shadow of another illness; or a consequence of some unseen ailment or the taking of strange substances. The Primary sleep disorders, Dyssomnias and Parasomnias, stand as sentinels. Dyssomnias –  Insomnia, Hypersomnia, Narcolepsy, Breathing-Related Sleep Disorder, Circadian Rhythm Sleep Disorder, and the unnamed Dyssomnia – these are the troubles that plague the act of sleeping itself. The Parasomnias, on the other hand, are the nightmares made flesh – Nightmare Disorder, Sleep Terror Disorder, Sleepwalking Disorder, and the rest, a symphony of unsettling occurrences. Sleep disorders entwined with other mental ailments are bound to the weight of Axis I (Clinical Disorders) or Axis II (Personality Disorders or Mental Retardation). This review, however, focuses on insomnia, a wanderer in the night, and the broader realm of primary sleep disorders, viewed through the lenses of the Biological and Sociocultural models.

The Biological model, a map of flesh and blood, points to the genes we inherit and the body's own whispers.  Neurons in the hypothalamus, those tiny stars in the darkness, contain orexin, the conductor of sleep and wakefulness.  One study, conducted on mice, has illuminated the presence of GABAB receptors on these orexin neurons, receptors that hold the key to sleep's embrace. When activated, they usher in the gentle embrace of sleep. But when silenced, anxiety recedes, and slumber comes calling. The GABAB agonist, baclofen, has been shown to lengthen the hours of sleep in these small creatures (Matsuki et al., 2009). This, perhaps, holds a mirror to our own sleep-deprived condition, suggesting that the genetic and environmental blueprints that shape these receptors in mice might echo in us as well. A flawed receptor, a missing piece, could be the silent architect of sleepless nights, a thief of rest, leaving us to grapple with the mundane and the meaningful alike. The Sociocultural implications are stark: If this phenotype is inherited, the ability to sleep, a fundamental human need, could be irrevocably altered. The impact, a ripple through the fabric of life, would touch the schoolroom, the workplace, and the everyday struggles of focus and concentration.

The wind whispers of a darkness in the ear, a hollowness where sound should be. This paper will speak of this shadow, of Central Auditory Processing Disorder, or CAPD as the learned men call it. First, a glimpse at the nature of the affliction. Then, the signs, the whispers that betray its presence. And finally, a path, a light in the dark, for those tasked with guiding a child through the labyrinth of sound.

CAPD, they say, is a failure of the mind to translate the world's whispers into meaning. The ear itself may catch the sound, but the brain, that great echo chamber, fails to make sense of it. It is a deafness of the soul, not of the ear. Words blur, voices blend, and the world becomes a cacophony of indistinguishable noise.

The shadow has been known since the mid-century, first called "auditory imperception."  Like a ghost, it has haunted the halls of science, studied by men like Bocca, Calearo, and Cassinari, and Kimura, who sought to map its presence. A conference in '77, a tremor in the earth, brought the whispers into the light.

CAPD wears many faces. It can be the inability to locate sound, to discern one voice from another, to follow the thread of a conversation. It can be the inability to hear the music in the world, the subtle shifts in tone that speak volumes. The world becomes a flat, featureless landscape where sound is but a dull roar.

To diagnose this affliction, one must listen closely, not just to the words, but to the silences, the hesitations, the missed cues. Tests abound, some simple, some complex, probing the mind for signs of the shadow. But there is no single key, no map to unravel its mystery. The cause, shrouded in darkness, remains elusive.

The play, Twelfth Night, it speaks to a kind of truth.  That disguise, while it can serve a purpose, a dark and twisting purpose, it can also devour a man whole.  To shed the mask, to return to the skin beneath, that's the hard part.  And in shedding it, one risks the cold hand of estrangement.  To hold onto the lie, or to cleave to those bound to you, that's the burden a man must bear.  Some may forgive the deception, some may not. And those who don't, they'll carry the sting of it like a brand.

The game of pretense, when it comes to gender,  it's a dangerous one.  Why does a soul choose to walk in another's shoes?  Why does it feel the need to bury its own face beneath a borrowed mask?  Viola, she found herself adrift, a castaway on a strange shore. She donned the guise of Cesario, a man's clothing, a man's name, a shield against the hungry eyes of the world.  "I'll bring you to a captain in this town / Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help / I was preserved to serve this noble count..."  These were the words she spoke, a promise whispered into the teeth of the storm.  But the mask, it isolates. It cuts a man off from the warmth of his own kind. And in this case, it even bloomed into a twisted love, a love born of misunderstanding. "Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay."  And the ghost of a love unacknowledged, a love that should never have been, lingered between Viola and Orsino.  "Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times / Thou never shouldst love woman like to me." 

This, perhaps, is the play's true heart.  That deception can force truth to the surface, to twist and writhe beneath the skin.  Did Olivia love Cesario for the man he pretended to be, or did she see a reflection of her own hidden desires?  A dangerous question, one that lingers in the shadows.  But the play offers no easy answers.  It is a story of masks and shadows, of love that blooms in the dark and truth that bleeds out like a wound.

The iron fist of the German Reich had left its mark on the land, a stain of blood on the sand. The Ovaherero and Namaqua, driven to their knees, their bones scattered like dust in the wind.  But a single brushstroke cannot capture the whole canvas.  The Kaiser’s empire, vast and sprawling, held within it a thousand shades of cruelty.  Each colony a whisper of a different song, sung in different tongues, under a thousand different suns.  

So it was with education.  In Tanganyika, the British found a people stirred, a spark of knowledge kindled by the Germans.  In Kamerun, too, the word spread, carried on the backs of birds and the whispers of the wind.  But in South West Africa, a different story unfolded.

There, the iron grip was tighter, colder.  The government, distant and uncaring, left the burden of teaching to the missionaries, their hands stained with the same blood that soaked the ground.  The whites, they were different.  They were given schools, their minds oiled with knowledge, their thirst for power quenched by schooling.  But the natives?  They were left to wander in the shadows, their spirits untamed, their minds untouched.

The scars of this neglect ran deep, a wound that festered long after the Germans had packed their bags and moved on.  While other colonies boasted of literate men and women, South West Africa remained steeped in darkness, a land where the majority remained silent, unlearned, and unseen.  

This is the story I seek to tell: the story of South West Africa, a story of neglect and indifference, a story of a people denied their birthright. I will delve into the heart of the matter, unearthing the whispers of the past, the secrets buried beneath the sands of time.  I will examine the attitudes of the settlers, the cold calculus of colonial power, and the weight of history that crushed the dreams of a nation.

The music they call popular, it's spread out like a stain across a century.  Genres bloom and wither, echoes of one another, rock and country, jazz and folk, all tangled together like weeds in a field. But the noise they call heavy metal, that's a different story. It's a thing that hungers, a beast with a thousand heads, each one howling its own darkness.

It started forty years back, a whisper in the shadows.  But soon enough, men saw the power in it, the way it could twist and turn, contort itself into something new.  They carved out their own little niches, their own private hells, each more elaborate than the last. Now the whole world's drowning in it.

They say it's music, this metal. But it's more than that. It's a fever dream, a soundtrack to the apocalypse. More bass, more volume, more fury than you could ever want.  It's a music of the flesh, the blood, the bone. It's a music that bleeds.

And in its veins, there runs a current of sickness. Drugs, they say.  The haze of the seventies, it seeped into the marrow of the music, turned their minds inside out. They chased the shadows, the ghosts in the machine. They found something dark down there, something primal, something terrifying. 

They sang of it, these metal men.  They sang of the darkness in us all, the beast that lies dormant beneath the skin. They sang of Helter Skelter, the Beatles' own descent into madness.  It was a warning, a glimpse into the abyss.  They were saying, listen. This is what happens when the music gets too loud.

The sun bled across the canvas, long shadows stretching from the trees like the limbs of some slumbering giant. A woman stood there, eyes wide as the night sky, adrift in a landscape spun from dreams. She was a figure from another time, another world, a world Henri Rousseau had built with his own hands. 

Decades before the Surrealists, before they bled their visions onto the white walls, Rousseau had been crafting his own dreams.  His brushstrokes, thick and deliberate, were the scaffolding of his desires. The Dream, that canvas from 1910, was more than just a woman lost in wonder. It was Rousseau himself, wrestling with the demons of ambition. He yearned for the accolades of the world, the whispers of praise from those who knew the weight of a brushstroke.  But the path to recognition was a thorny one. 

He could walk the well-worn paths of convention, mimicking the styles that hung in the gilded galleries, or he could forge his own way, his own truth, a path that might lead to solitude. The choice, like the dream itself, was a perilous one.

Rousseau's story was etched in the dust of his own life. Born into the bourgeois world, he had known neither the solace of fine art training nor the luxury of early acclaim. He toiled for the state, a gabelou, a man of numbers and tollbooths. His dreams were a refuge, a balm for the wounds inflicted by loss. He had buried children, wives, and dreams in the cold earth.  

But the hunger for recognition gnawed at him. He saw the masters, the prodigies who rose to fame in the Parisian salons, and he felt the sting of inadequacy.  He was an outsider, a man who painted with the heart of a peasant, not the polish of a Parisian.

Jan Gordon, in his book on the modern French painters, spoke of a kind of kinship between Rousseau and Matisse, two men who stood on opposite sides of the art world's divide. Matisse, a man who feared banality, and Rousseau, a man who craved acceptance.  Two souls driven by a thirst, one for originality, the other for belonging.

The old talk, the one about beauty being truth and truth beauty, it ain't just talk.  There's a bone deep reason for it. Keats, he knew it.  "Beauty is truth, truth beauty," he said.  That's all you need to know, he said.

We learn a lot in life.  From books, from streets, from the sting of experience. But these things, ethics and beauty, they seep in different. You can't teach them like addition or the names of birds. They're not rules to be followed, but whispers in the dark. We try to explain them, sure, dissect a painting or a poem, talk about its parts. But it ain't the brushstrokes that make the Mona Lisa sing, or the words on the page that make a story bleed truth. There's a something, a ghost in the machine, that can't be nailed down.

O'Connor, she knew it too. A story, she said, is a way to say what can't be said. A statement, that's too small.

Even when we describe a thing to death, there's still a gap. An echo. And that's where the power lies. Wittgenstein, he said it plain: ethics can't be spoken. It's beyond words.  That's the connection between art and morality, that thing that sings in the bones. They both touch a place we can't quite reach.

Literature, it's the closest. McKean, he said it lives and breathes values. It's not just entertainment, it's a mirror held up to what matters. And maybe that's what makes us human, this need to find meaning in the messy beauty of it all.

The German lands. They call it a strong nation now. United. A tapestry woven from the shadows of the Alps in München's cold embrace, stretching to Kiel's salt-bitten shores. This same blood runs through Köln, a river city on the Rhine, through the heart of the land, and out to Dresden, a Saxon city clinging to the Elbe. A land forged from many fires, many stories. 

Germania. The name itself a whisper from the past, a ghost story debated by men with books. Tacitus, he claimed it came from the Tungrians, a tribe before they crossed the Rhine, before the clash with the Gauls. (Tacitus, 98.) Caesar, he used the word "Germanus" in his tales of Gaul, a line drawn in the sand between the conquered and the unconquered. From the Gauls themselves he took it, a word to mark the difference. Some say it meant neighbor, a sound in a tongue long gone. Caesar, in the first chapter of his first book, wrote: "Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (The Gauls) are continually waging war.....They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles." (Julius Caesar, 50-40 BC) Others speak of a spear, a "ger", or a shout, "garim", a word from the ancient Irish. The Germans, they were loud, they were fierce.

Tacitus, that old Roman, he wrote in his "De Origine et situ Germanorum," a tale of beginnings. "I should regard (The Germans) as aboriginal," he wrote. "Not mixed, not touched by other races.  Who would leave the warmth of Asia, the sun-baked sands of Africa, for this land? For Germany, with its wild heart, its skies that weep, its people with eyes that hold the shadows?" (Tacitus, 98) 

And who would leave Rome for Germania? Not the Romans, not yet. They would come for trade, for gold, for the trinkets that whispered of a wilder land. They would come with their legions, their swords glinting in the sun, but they would go back, back to the empire that sprawled like a beast beneath the sun.

The Germanic tribes, they lived on the edges, on the border of the Roman world. They traded their wares, their furs and their skills. Some joined the ranks of the Roman legions, soldiers of fortune. (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17.)

Down I looked. The view a blank slate against the gray. Mind a still pond, reflecting without feeling. Eyes sharp, studying the contours, the shapes, the shades, but the mind, it held back. Thoughts flickered like fireflies, in and out, never settling. It was like a film passing through, a rush of images, no real meaning, just the cold, hard truth of what was there.

Once, a man I worked with, a painter, he gave me a book. "The New Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain" it was called. Said it could teach a man to see. To see the world not as it seemed, but as it was.  I'd wanted to draw since I was a boy, always watching, always wanting to capture the world on paper. The book, it talked about lines, about how the brain took those lines and made them mean something. It talked about framing, about taking a cluttered scene, a bowl of fruit on a table in a room, and making it simple, just the bowl, just the fruit, just the plane it sat on.

At that moment, staring down at this bowl, this brown bowl, I couldn't see the frame. I was lost in the details, the texture of the brown, the way it sat in the bowl, the way the light caught the curve of the sides. Picasso had his blues, Monet his greens, the Italians, they painted rainbows. If I was to paint, if I was to make something, this was it. This was the start. My brown world.

My hand reached out, fingers trembling, towards the brush, a stick of wood and bristles. Muscles tense, then relax, the hand moving, trying to make sense of the world. This could be it. This could be the moment.

Water swirled, smooth and clear. A piece broke off, floated away, lost in the gray. Muscles tightened again, a jerky motion, a frantic push. The handle slammed against the porcelain. The brown, it wouldn't move. Stuck, clinging to the bottom of the bowl like a burr on a dog's fur.


A mop, held loosely in my hand. Feet planted, tie a noose around my neck.  I stared at the brown mess, the offering left by some nameless soul. A few more flushes, a few more moments of silence, then my hand reached out, grabbed the paper, and began to wrap myself in it, like a mummy, until all that was left was a pale, white shape against the brown.

Straightening, I bent down, my hand dipped into the bowl. A mother reaching into a hot oven, taking out her offering.

The young ones are dying behind the wheel. A reckoning unfolds in the steel and glass cages they call cars. The sickness lies deep, in the marrow of the adolescent brain, not yet formed for the weight of the road. Inexperience, a hollow echo in the steel canyons, a siren song to the grave.  More crashes, more spills, more recklessness. Speeding, veering, a dance with oblivion.

They ride with their kind, these young ones, a pact sealed in the back seat. The numbers tell the tale, etched in blood and metal. California, a land of sun and shadows, has tried to hold them back, a provisional shield, a leash on the wild heart. But it's a bandage on a broken limb.

The truth is, they're not ready. Not for the burden of the wheel, not for the cold geometry of the highway. A doctor, Zuckerman, calls it a sickness, a yearning for the sting of the abyss. Eighteen, he says, too young. They crave the rush, the surge of adrenaline, the kiss of danger.

The tide is coming, a wave of young blood, the children of the boomers, eager and reckless.  They'll flood the roads, a storm of steel and flesh. Unchecked, the death toll will rise, a mountain in the desert of their lives.

We must act. No more licenses for the young.  Let them learn, let them study, let them feel the weight of the responsibility. Sixteen, seventeen, eighteen—let them wait. Let the wildness subside, let the hunger for death abate.

Then, when they're ready, when the road whispers a promise instead of a threat, let them take the wheel. Until then, let them walk, let them learn, let them live.

The Library of Congress, a repository of old things, held a collection of Edison’s flickering pictures. Fifteen of them, these trick films, from the time before the turn of the century. Illusions, they were, woven from the threads of edited moments.  

I saw them, these ghosts of a forgotten age, and tried to make sense of their strange poetics. Most were bound to a stage, a proscenium arch framing their silent drama. The camera, a watchful eye, never moved. Long shots, medium shots, that was all. No close-ups, no intimacy. It was the theatre they mimicked, the vaudeville, the magic shows, where the whole was seen at once. The figures moved side-to-side, confined by the proscenium's confines.

Like actors in Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel (1900), they walked the stage, never coming closer, never receding.

Each picture, a thought, a single idea captured. One shot, one film. A minute or less, fleeting as smoke. These were not stories, not in the way we understand them. They were tricks, fleeting moments of wonder, magic, a vanished hand, a sudden disappearance. 

But look closer, at The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots (1895). The head, severed, a phantom, a moment of illusion built from a joining of glimpses.

John Taylor of Caroline, a man of the soil, a farmer through and through, he was. Republicanism ran in his blood, a fire that burned bright in his belly. His life, bound to the earth, had forged him into a man of conviction, a voice raised in defense of freedom, against the creeping hand of government.  His creed, born of the fields, bled into every thought, every word he spoke. He saw the good in the land, in the sweat of man’s brow, and believed it the foundation of a just society.  

He saw in the young nation a chance to forge something new, unburdened by the ghosts of old. No king, no tradition to bind them. A government of the people, by the people, he believed, was the only true path.  He spoke of natural rights, of a balance delicate as a spider’s web, where the denial of one thread unravelled the whole. These rights, he said, must be kept from the grasp of power, for they were the lifeblood of a free man. He saw the state of nature, the brutal world before civilization, where strength ruled and the wicked prospered. But in this new world, he preached, there must be another way.

To build this ideal, he argued, government must be tempered by the very nature of man. Good and evil, he believed, were woven into the fabric of our being.  He saw government as a mirror, reflecting the virtues and vices of its creators. He spoke of  principles, the bedrock of a just society - the protection of property, the nurturing of the land, the restraint of unchecked greed. He believed that even the most flawed government, if built on these principles, could find some measure of fairness. For he knew, as a farmer knows the seasons, that self-interest was the engine of man. But it could be harnessed, turned to the common good, or it could lead to ruin, to a world where the strong devoured the weak.

A strict construction, he demanded of the Constitution. A government limited, restrained, its power confined to the words written on the page. He feared the reach of a sprawling federal power, its cost breeding tyranny. But he knew that a literal reading, devoid of intent, could be a dangerous weapon in the hands of the ambitious.  He looked to the Declaration of Independence, not the Constitution, as the true charter of the nation. It spoke of sovereign states, a union of equals, not a singular entity.

The figures, they spoke of a fall. A steep one, in the third month.  December.  Snow falling on the New England ground, a shroud upon the campus. Fewer bicycles, fewer feet on the path. The semester's end, a flurry of papers and grades, a weight settling on the mind.  The log, it slipped from the frayed edges of their memory. The holidays, a long shadow stretching across the month, a time for leaving, for absence. January, the silence of a new year, the campus bare.  Then, a flicker. A spark, perhaps, in March. The Carpool Challenge, a last gasp of effort. A brief surge in the numbers. But the truth, it lingered like smoke in the air. The natural ebb and flow. The pull of the machine.

They say freedom lies in the wheel. It's a song woven into the fabric of this land. A siren song. To break free, you need a lure, a whisper of something more. Gifts, they offered. Small tokens, trinkets of comfort. Coffee, books, massages. A taste, a glimpse of something else. But what of a grander prize? A bicycle, gleaming in the sun. A machine that runs on air. A car that whispers of a different future. A promise of something more. Perhaps then, the numbers would rise, a testament to the changing tide.

The thing they call an ETF. A packaged security. Designed to track some marker, some index, maybe a commodity or a whole basket of things. Like an index fund, but more nimble. Trades like stock on a board.

It offers the spread of the index fund, sure. But with the bite of a single share. You can short, you can go on margin, buy a single goddamn share. The fees though, they're leaner than a starving dog.  

But there's a cost. A commission each time you move. Like a toll on the road. 

And the variety, it's vast.  A whole goddamn ocean of choices.

But a smart man, he questions everything.  He looks at those promises, those benefits, diversification, and asks: how deep do they run?

We'll be lookin' at this IHF thing.  Comparing it to its top ten holdings. See if the whole is truly greater than the sum of its parts. See if there's a better way to stack those stones, a tighter grip on the return, a lower tilt in the wind.

We ain't got time to measure every goddamn piece.  So we'll focus on the ten big ones. They hold most of the weight, 63.58% of the whole damn thing.

We'll see what these ten say about the IHF.  We'll calculate their beta, their return, how they move together.  See if they whisper the same song as the whole damn chorus.

The numbers tell a story. The top ten, they offer a return 6.11% higher. A goddamn sixteen percent jump. And their beta, it's a shade lower, a little more steady.

But is it enough?  Are these differences real, or just a whisper in the wind?  We gotta dig deeper, see if the data holds water.  We'll measure the standard deviation, the spread of those ten stocks. See if it matches up to the IHF.

The truth, it's out there somewhere.  We just gotta dig it up.

Dream-Land. One of Poe's own words, he called it a good one. A poem where the word Thulé, it appears twice, like a shadow, in lines six and fifty-six. Mabbott, he says it comes from Virgil, an old man with a fancy for islands north of Britain. An island the Greeks thought was the edge of everything. Virgil, he used it, that much is sure. But there's another road, a more recent one, that some whisper about. Poe, he was drawn to the German tongue, to the dark whispers of their words. 

This quote, it speaks of a familiarity, a knowing. Arndt, in his book about Poe and Goethe, he sees the marks of imitation, a reflection in the mirror. Two poems, two souls grappling with the same deep well of sorrow. 

Oxford, they call it a Companion, this book of English Literature. Inside, it speaks of Goethe, a man who built his name on the play Faust, a story in two parts, the first a sigh in the year 1808, the second a death rattle in 1832. But within the second part, a smaller poem resides, a whisper called "The King of Thulé". A king, his queen gone, a goblet left behind. He drinks, he weeps, remembers. His grief, a tide that drowns him. He gives away his treasures, keeps only the goblet, a reminder of the light that's gone. He walks to the edge, the sea a dark maw below, throws the goblet in, closes his eyes, and lets go. 

The King of Thulé, a shadow of Poe's own darkness. A reflection in the abyss. Faust, it took form on the stage in 1842, a year before Poe used Thulé in "The Pit and the Pendulum". A year that echoed with the ghosts of loss. 

Thulé, it appears twice in Poe's works. In "The Pit and the Pendulum", he whispers "ultma Thule". But in "Dream-Land", it frames the poem, a bookend to a world consumed by sorrow. "The King of Thulé" and "Dream-Land", twin poems, born from the same wellspring of despair. The speaker in "Dream-Land", he steps into Goethe's world, a world of darkness, of loneliness, of ghosts that haunt the edges of memory. A world where color fades, and only the echoes of loss remain. 

Goethe, a giant in the world of words, a name Poe would have known, even if it was only through the reverence he held for Tennyson. 

But there were other paths, other ways to encounter Goethe's work. Reproductions, whispers carried on the wind, a world where his words found new homes.

The law in California, it speaks of malice. A customer, she slips and falls on a mess of applesauce, a spilled offering in the maw of the grocery store. Could this court, might it see fit to award her not just for the hurt she’s suffered, but also for the sting of a punishment, a reckoning for the man who ran the store?

A judge, he’s not likely to toss out the woman’s claim, not so easily. To win the right for such a punishment, she must show that the store manager’s actions were deliberate, a disregard for the hurt that might come. His heart, it must have been cold, knowing the danger, knowing what might befall another soul. She’ll say that he knew, the manager, that the slick floor was a threat.  Spills like this, they’d happened before, others had fallen.  He’d been warned twice, once by one man, then another. Yet he chose to eat his dinner while the danger lay in wait.

But the woman, she’ll have to argue harder still that the manager’s heart was truly black, that he was not just careless but cruel. Six times before in that year, folks had fallen, tripped, hurt themselves on the slick floors of his store.  He’d seen the danger, and he’d turned away.

She says it happened on a day in October, the thirteenth to be exact. A clock struck five, and a worker told the manager, this Paul Martin. Applesauce, he’d been told, a puddle in the aisle. “Dinner break,” the manager said, “no time for complaints.” Fifteen minutes passed, another worker, Mary J. Haddigan, she warned him again. Same answer. By half past five, the woman, Jennifer Palmer, she slipped and fell. Her back, it was broken, her life forever changed.


The law in California, it speaks of malice. This manager, he knew the danger. Six times he’d been warned. Did he act with malice? Did he act with a heart that was cold?

Four years gone now. A semester spent under the fluorescent hum of CBC's classrooms, wrestling with the question of Islam.  Hostile faith they called it.  A question whispered then, a question that now echoes louder than ever.  The world since the fall, a pendulum swing from fear to an almost suffocating acceptance. Could a man named Obama, with the ghost of his heritage clinging to him like a shroud, ever have worn the mantle of President back then?  

The Prophet's biography, a tangled thread of contradictions.  I'd heard the stories, the tales of conquest and forced conversion.  A sword at the throat, Islam the price of survival.  But this book, it painted a different picture.  A martyr misunderstood, a man humbled, seeking truth in the dust.  They say the people came to him, drawn by some unseen light.

And there's a strange echo, a resonance between the ministries of these men, Jesus and Muhammad.  The multiplication of mutton and milk, a whispered miracle, a shared hunger.  A deliberate mirroring, perhaps, to elevate Muhammad, to cast him as a man of truth, a silent, unassuming force.  But it feels like a theft, a shadow play where one light steals the brilliance of another.

The stories, too, they feel manufactured, stacked like cards in a house of cards.  He heard from her, she heard from him, a whisper chain stretching back into the desert.  Proof, they say, of the truth's enduring power.  But the distance, the layers, they cast a shadow on the story itself, a whisper of doubt.

The biographer's intent, to lift Muhammad to a pedestal, to crown him with humility and wisdom.  But history, a stubborn thing, whispers a different tale.  Can those who follow him, those who claim his mantle, truly know the man behind the myth?

The word of the man from Nazareth, his own teachings, they were cast aside like a worn cloak in the years after his passing.  Christianity, a river swollen by time, flowed on, ever changing its course.  The world, a restless beast, moved forward, a tide of progress washing over all.  The old ways clung to the shores, but their voices were faint, lost in the roar of the current.  A hunger will rise in the hearts of men, a yearning to sift through the layers of dogma, to find the man, the man beneath the monument.  It will take time, decades, perhaps centuries, but the tide will turn.  The river will run back up its course, seeking the source.

The doctrines, the pronouncements, they will fall away, one by one, like stones from a crumbling wall, until only the echo of his voice remains.  Across the land, in the halls of the church, the faithful will gather, their heads bowed, their ears open to the whisper of his words.  But the church, it will remain, a fortress of faith against the storm.  And though the river flows backward, the waters will run clear, the faith will find its unity.

History is a wheel, turning ever onward, yet always returning to its center.  The Empire that once persecuted the followers of the Nazarene, it became the vessel of their faith.  The chains of slavery, they too fell, giving way to the rise of a new order.

Now, the wheel turns once more, seeking the heart of the matter.  The differences, the factions, they will dissolve, leaving behind a single, clear image of the man, the man who walked the earth.  And in his words, not as pronouncements, but as whispers, as parables, the truth will be found.

Look back, far back, to the time before the man.  Look to the people who walked the dusty roads of Judea.  They were a diverse people, divided by their own beliefs, the Sadducees, the Pharisees, the Essenes, all seeking the face of God.  Theirs was a faith, ancient and deep, a root from which the tree of Christianity would grow.

The muck of it all. That's what Sinclair shows you. The hunger in men's bellies ain't just for food. It's for power, for more. The bosses, they're all the same. They build their empires of brick and steel, smoke billowing like a shroud against the sky. They see nothing but their own reflection in the glass towers, nothing of the grime clinging to the lives they grind beneath their wheels. 

He paints a picture, stark and black, of the river of filth flowing from their factories, a sickness seeping into the ground, the air, the very bones of the city.  They don't care for the men who toil in the shadows, the men broken and bleeding in the name of progress. A dollar, that's all they see. A dollar and the endless churning of the machine, chewing up men and spitting them out like waste.

Sinclair speaks of a cauldron, seething with hate and jealousy.  Loyalty? Decency?  Lost in the stench of sweat and despair.  They'll lay you off with a flick of the wrist, no warning, no mercy. The law? A whisper in the wind.  The workers, they're slaves to a system built on their backs, their bodies broken, their dreams turned to dust.

He calls them slaves, and the word hangs heavy in the air.  Men trapped in a cage of their own making, their lives dictated by the whims of men who see them as nothing more than cogs in a machine. There's no escape, no light at the end of the tunnel. Just the endless grind, the gnawing hunger, and the crushing weight of a world that cares nothing for their souls.

Some writers, they spin their words like a spider, weaving a web to catch the feelin' of a thing. They use tricks, these writers, some more cunning than others. Fitzgeral, he was a master of the trick. In his story, *The Great Gatsby*, he took words and slapped 'em together like mismatched puzzle pieces, makin' somethin' strange and new. He'd find a word, a color say, and give it a weight, a meaning that hung heavy in the air. Gold, green, white, red - these were his tools. He'd build a meaning around 'em, then use 'em to paint a picture, to make you feel somethin'. 

White and gray, these were his favorites. White, he made it mean somethin' clean, fancy, like a rich man's linen shirt. Gray, that was older, faded, like a memory lost in the dust. He planted these seeds early, all through the book. Everyone was wearin' white, like ghosts in a summer haze. Daisy, Jordan, Nick - all swathed in white. Even the way he talks about the parties, it's all white and dull, like a bleached bone.

Then there's gray. The names, the cars, the land - all swallowed up by the grayness. Like the world itself was turnin' to ash. He took these colors, white and gray, and used them to show you somethin' about the people, about what they were really worth. Daisy, she becomes a ghost in white, a shell of a woman, floatin' through the story like a wisp of smoke.  

Fitzgerald, he knew how to use a color like a weapon. He'd paint a picture, and you'd feel it in your bones. That's the power of his words, the power of his vision.

The San Diego sun beats down on a land fat with bounty. Tomatoes ripe for the picking, citrus heavy on the branches, greens unfolding like emerald hands. Squash, broccoli, herbs, peaches, lemons, berries, honey, peppers – all flourish in this Eden of plenty. A hunger for the pure and the simple has taken hold, a demand for what grows from the earth unburdened. The people line up, lists in hand, yearning for the bounty of the organic harvest. Eggs, milk, the cream of the land, all free from the taint of artifice.

These same farms, they open their gates, inviting the curious in. Hikers tread paths between rows, their eyes drawn to the flitting wings of birds, the whisper of the wind through the leaves. A lesson learned, a connection forged, the land yielding its secrets. This, then, is the promise – to till the soil with care, to reap the rewards, and to offer a glimpse of the wild heart of the world.

The earth remembers. It yearns for balance.  Chemical poisons have poisoned the soil, choked the life from the land.  Organic farming, it whispers, a return to the ancient ways.  But it demands a different kind of labor, a patient hand, a constant vigilance.  To nurture the soil, to coax life from the earth, it requires sweat and toil. Losses are heavier, harvests smaller.

The path is not paved with gold, but with grit and determination. Planting cover crops, grazing with purpose, battling the encroaching weeds, it all takes its toll.  Yet the rewards are greater than mere profit. The land sings a song of abundance, a symphony of life.  A haven for the endangered, a refuge for the weary, a testament to the enduring spirit of the wild.

The land itself, it tells a story.  Cracked earth, chaparral clinging to life, a whisper of oak trees stretching towards the sky. A hundred species, some teetering on the edge, others rebuilding their lost dominion. The kangaroo rat, a phantom fleeting through the brush, the yellow-legged frog, a splash of color in a sun-baked pool. The gnatcatcher, a song on the wind, a reminder that even in this hardened land, beauty persists. 

This land has seen the hand of man, the tread of cattle, the ghosts of homesteaders long gone. Now, a new chapter begins, a promise whispered on the breeze. To heal the earth, to honor the past, to build a future where man and nature walk side by side.

Culture. A word worn thin by use. It ain't no thing you can hold in your hand. More like a shadow, stretching long and thin, defining the space a man moves in. It's what ain't there that matters as much as what is.  

To say all Russians are stubborn is to miss the point.  Like saying all deserts are sand. Sure, there's sand. But there's wind too. And heat. And secrets buried deep.

Understandin' a culture ain't about boxes and labels. It's about the dirt beneath your boots, the language on your tongue, the ghosts that whisper in your ear.

When you walk into a room, you see it through the lens of your own past. Comparisons rise up like smoke. But tryin' to change a culture is like tryin' to dam the river. It'll find a way around.

Best to respect the currents. Learn the flow.  See the world through their eyes. Even when you're on shaky ground, a little respect can go a long way.

And culture ain't just about borders. It's the walls inside a company too. Some places run on long hours and deadlines. Others on whispers and coffee breaks.  It's in the clothes they wear, the words they use, the way they treat each other.

Values. Now those are the heart of a culture. What they hold dear. What they fear. 

If a man's gotta save face, he ain't gonna stab his boss in the back to win a deal. And if a woman's gotta drive a hard bargain, she ain't gonna back down easy.

Know your enemy. Know their values. Know yourself. That's the key to any deal worth closin'.

The fool has said it, in the dark corners of his heart: "There is no God." These words, carved from the psalm stones of the Book, mark the opening of Anselm's inquiry. He seeks to prove the Lord, the God of the scriptures, a God bound by the pages of belief. Aquinas, another traveler on this path, holds the same conviction. But the question hangs heavy: whose argument rings truest? To answer that, we must first accept the premise, for the sake of this reckoning, that both these men believe in the same God, the God of the Bible. To wander from that path, to consider other gods, would be to stray from the heart of their discourse.

Yet, while both men grapple with the weight of the question, neither, I would argue, lays bare a foundation strong enough to stand against the winds of doubt.

Anselm's journey begins within. He seeks the proof of God not in the rustle of leaves or the crash of waves, but in the chambers of the soul. His God is a truth, a concept, bound by the very act of understanding.  He posits that to conceive of God's absence is to fail to grasp the very nature of existence itself. His logic is a tangled web of faith, where the unseen is made known through the lens of the mind.  Anselm tells us to look inward, to find the Lord etched upon the tablets of our own being.

Aquinas, however, seeks a different kind of proof. He lays down five pillars of logic, each one a sturdy argument for the existence of God. Change, he argues, points to a mover. Causation demands a first cause. Contingency whispers of a necessary being. Degrees of excellence point to a supreme being.
